—Will the Treasurer inform the House of the current strength of the Australian economy and the steps that the Government has taken to ensure that Australia continues to expand its productive base while curbing the growth in demand?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The economy is currently showing considerable strength. The Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd job vacancy series in October rose by 4.1 per cent and was 21 per cent higher than a year earlier. Employment has grown by 315,000 jobs in the year to September, which is an increase of 4.4 per cent. The trend level of unemployment has fallen to 6.9 per cent, compared with 8 per cent 12 months earlier. This strength is coming from rapid growth in private investment and expanding exports. Importantly, it is not coming from private consumption or from public demand. Indeed, retail sales fell by 0.7 per cent in August, following a fall of 2 per cent in July, and public spending will fall again in 1988-89.

ANSWER.PARA: The Budget forecast of business investment was for an increase of 12 per cent in 1988-89 following an increase of 10 per cent last year. Industry surveys for the September quarter show that a major re-equipment and capacity expansion is under way in manufacturing. Investment in the services sector is also very strong. Investment in residential housing has increased rapidly, growing by 11.4 per cent last year, and will grow by 12 per cent or more this year. Subdued private consumption, declining public demand, strong private investment and expanding exports have not come about by accident. We have reduced the net public sector borrowing requirement to zero through cutting outlays and giving the private sector something to allocate. We have made our trade sector highly competitive through a sensible wages policy and a market determined exchange rate, and also because we have been willing to use monetary policy in its proper balancing role.

After the October stock market crash, monetary policy was eased to help the liquidity of the financial system and to maintain confidence. Other countries took similar steps. In the June quarter monetary policy was tightened as the economy weathered the crash and started to pick up speed. The Government responded more rapidly than governments of other Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries. Since then the Government has not stood in the way of market moves to lift interest rates. The market has been responding to the general strength of the economy along with a higher than expected consumer price index and a temporary shortfall in export receipts brought about by the diminished supply of some rural exports. In this way, monetary policy has tightened further and the Government has complied in this tightening because it would be foolhardy to allow an already strong economy to run ahead even faster.

If we are to build the productive base that we need to permanently repair our trading balance, we have to proceed at a sustainable pace. In this way growth will not only be maintained this year but we will have the basis for further growth next year. We are now in the very enviable position of having to manage strength, and that strength is beginning to flow right through the economy. Employment growth has been exceptionally strong-the participation rate is up, boosting the income of individual households in a major way; real household disposable income is likely to grow by something closer to 4 per cent than to the 3 per cent contained in the Budget forecast; incomes are up because of strong employment growth; and high farm incomes and real wages will also increase this year.

The Government will continue with its policy framework because it is working and because it is delivering benefits. We will continue to stop demand running too rapidly by keeping public spending tight and also keeping monetary policy appropriately tight. We will continue to keep the economy competitive while we boost our productive capacity through strong investment growth. In short, we will make sure that we have a solid basis to boost household disposable income further next year through a properly structured wage-tax deal which will cut inflation and deliver the benefits of the sharp reduction in the size of the Commonwealth government that we have achieved to date.

—Madam Speaker, it is lovely to see you back in the chair. My question, to the Minister for Community Services and Health, relates to the proposal of the Australian Medical Association (AMA) for a new fee structure for general practitioners (GPs). Can the Minister inform the House of the outcome of discussions between the Government and the Australian Medical Association about the new fee schedule?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I regret to inform honourable members that the AMA has rejected the Government's quite generous offer to develop jointly a new fee for GPs. Let me make quite clear what I have offered the AMA, because there is some distortion in some of the comments it has made. I offered to set up a working party of the Government and the medical profession to develop jointly the AMA proposal when I met with the AMA and other medical groups last Tuesday. I undertook to ensure that the working party's deliberations were completed expeditiously and that, depending on the successful outcome of those discussions, consideration would then be given to the fee levels. The offer was conditional upon the AMA also showing some good faith in return, some goodwill, by requesting that the few doctors who had decided to implement the AMA structure continued charging under the existing system until the completion of the working party's discussions. In other words, in return for the offer made by the Government, in good faith, we requested some good faith on the part of the AMA. The AMA delegates with whom I discussed this issue did not reject that out of hand, but by the time they got back to their executive, the proposal was rejected.

ANSWER.PARA: Naturally, I am disappointed by the intractability of the AMA on this important issue. I am also more disappointed that the AMA has now resorted to untruths in an attempt to conceal its stubborn attitude on this issue. Indeed, the poverty of the AMA's case can now be seen in the dishonesty of the arguments it is presenting. Let me refer to three arguments which appeared in the Canberra Times this morning. An article in today's issue of the Canberra Times quotes the AMA's director of communications, Mr Mason, as saying that I had had since 14 September to talk to the AMA about delaying implementation of its proposal. Of course, that is true. That is why on 15 September, and repeatedly since then, I have invited the AMA to talk to the Government before attempting to introduce its fee proposals. But it took the AMA until 27 October, six weeks after it announced its proposed structure, to accept that invitation. Even then it only agreed to talk on 1 November, that is, the day of implementation. That deals with that tale.

The second of the points made in the article was that I am opposing the principle of a content-based system. I have never opposed the principle of a content-based system. I have rightly challenged some of the details of the AMA proposal. The Government finds the fee level unacceptable. At that meeting with the AMA there were representatives of other parts of the medical profession. They know that statement of mine to be true and what has been published by the AMA to be untrue. At that meeting and beforehand I indicated that I did not oppose the principle, even though we had concerns about some of the details.

In the same article the AMA President, Dr Phillips, stated that my failure to endorse the AMA proposal is contradictory to my support of the Canadian health system. It is true that I find much to admire in the Canadian health system. I am extraordinarily glad that the AMA now seems to have a new-found enthusiasm for the Canadian health system. One of the most attractive features of the Canadian health system is that it has effective provisions which prevent doctors from charging above the schedule fee. I welcome the AMA's enthusiasm for such a system. Of course, the AMA's proposed fee structure bears little relationship to the Canadian system. It has simply copied those aspects of the system that it likes, rejected all the others and neglected entirely issues of patient and government accountability. That is why the great majority of general practitioners in this country have rejected the AMA proposals.

—My question is for the Minister for Employment and Education Services. I ask: As today we are celebrating the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Women's Bureau can the Minister advise the House of recent gains made by women in the areas of education, employment and training?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Phillip for her question. Every member of the House knows the keen interest she takes in this particular matter. It is, of course, true that this is the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Women's Bureau, which was established in 1963. As such, I would expect that all members of the House would join me in congratulating the Bureau on the fine work it has done since it was established 25 years ago. Of course, since that time the Bureau has received support in its work from governments of all persuasions. This Government has been particularly supportive of the thrust of the Bureau's work. Under this Government major advances have been made on the part of women in the area of employment, education and training.

ANSWER.PARA: For example, it is true that, while year 12 retention rates overall have gone up substantially, the lift in the retention rates for young women has been more substantial than for young men. They went up from 43.9 per cent in 1983 to 57 per cent in 1987-a quite remarkable achievement in anybody's terms.

It is also true that the unemployment rate for women was 7.6 per cent in September 1988, which was higher by one percentage point than the rate for men at 6.6 per cent. But it needs to be remembered that in 1983-84 the unemployment rate for women was 2.5 percentage points higher than the rate for men. In addition, the current unemployment rate reflects strong growth in the labour force since 1983 and conceals quite outstanding gains that have been made by women.

Women have been the major beneficiary of the massive job growth that has occurred under this Administration. Fifty-eight per cent of all new jobs have gone to women. Female job growth has averaged around 4.5 per cent annually compared with only 1.6 per cent under the Fraser-Howard Administration. The proportion of women aged 15 years and over in the labour force has risen by about 5.5 percentage points since April 1983.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business would be aware of the reissue of a plastic $10 banknote. Would he provide the House with information about the technology developed to enable provision of banknotes made of plastic and their export potential?

—I thank the honourable member for Hinkler for his question. I think honourable members are quite interested in the development of the $10 note. It has been a long time coming, but we think it has very considerable export potential. When I took samples of the $10 note to the United States and Japan there was real interest for future development from corporations there. The use of the holographic technique on a diffraction grating is significantly better--
—Are you going to give us each a sample?

—I will have to ask the Treasurer about that; he is responsible for the note issue. We have a high quality project which is essentially dependent on extremely sophisticated and complex mathematics. When the last $10 note was produced, we found that it was reproducible photographically and, of course, with the use of more sophisticated techniques in colour reproduction, it was comparatively easy to run off very high quality forgeries. We have to be very careful about making any kind of absolute statement that cannot be contradicted but, as far as we can tell, this note seems to be forgery proof. First of all, there is a diffraction grating and a formula which is read into the metallicised picture of Captain Cook, which is based on something very complex, but a concept with which the Opposition ought to be familiar, called `catastrophe theory'. It is very complex mathematics, involving a series of differential equations where all the solutions come together at one point. The one point will be the brightest spot, on the image. Just think of the implications, not only for banknotes. We know that the Reserve Bank of Australia has the monopoly on it for Australia, but what we are interested in is the economic potential for making banknotes in all the other major countries of the world, and the potential for all sorts of legal documents that involve security checks, for travellers cheques, for credit cards, and so on. We ought to be very proud of the effort of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. There is no doubt that in this very important area it is quite legitimately regarded as the world leader.

—I address my question to the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel. Is the Minister aware of a recent report in the Brisbane Courier-Mail about a Defence Force family whose twin sons, aged five, were not permitted to attend school in Queensland even though they had attended two years of preschool and seven months of preparatory school at their father's previous posting in Victoria? Can the Minister say what steps she has taken to help this family? What can be done to help Defence Force families with school age children as they move between different State education systems?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kelly The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for her question. I did see the story to which she refers and, in fact, the case was familiar to me. I learned of that family's case a few months ago, and on 6 October I wrote to Mrs Christie, to my colleague the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, telling him about the situation, to the south-east Queensland delegate of the National Consultative Group of Service Spouses and to the Queensland Minister for education. In the letter, I highlighted to them the problem that this family faced. Of course their problems are typical of the problems that many Defence Force families face-in fact, mobile families face-as they travel around Australia, with the different State education systems.

ANSWER.PARA: The issue has been of great concern to me during my time in the portfolio and it is an area upon which I have decided to take action. So on 21 October I submitted a report to the Australian Education Council (AEC) meeting in Melbourne. The report entitled Some examples of educational disadvantage experienced by children of Service families is a collection of case histories gathered from defence families around Australia and, of course, the case of the Christie twins was only one example covered in the report. The report is available if anyone would like a copy of it. I am delighted with the results of that meeting.
The Australian Education Council considered mobility issues at its meeting on 21 October and passed a resolution, which I quote to the House:
to implement practical ways to eliminate or minimise the effect of unnecessary differences between school systems.

One of the `practical ways' will be to give `sympathetic consideration' to the `requirements of students moving between systems with different enrolment policies'. Defence Force families are obviously aware of the differences between State education systems, and they know that those problems cannot be ironed out overnight, but Minister Dawkins has obviously taken this issue to heart, and I thank him on behalf of Defence Force families and other mobile families for his work in this matter.

I should add that the AEC has also resolved to consider the adoption of student information portfolios, which is an initiative of mine which has been introduced on a pilot basis with children of Defence Force families throughout Australia. The portfolio eases the transition of students between schools by giving them a portable record of their achievements, their skills, their interests and their educational history.

I regret that we cannot solve this problem overnight, but I give the honourable member and her constituents and Defence Force constituents throughout Australia a commitment that this is an issue which the Government is concerned about and cares about, and is working towards resolving.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Industrial Relations inform the House of the opportunities that may arise to improve the position of women in the workplace through award restructuring?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for her question. As honourable members know, award restructuring is aimed at making Australian industry more efficient and more competitive both at home and overseas. It also aims to shape employment opportunities and to improve the quality of life for all Australian employees, including women.

ANSWER.PARA: Along with other Government initiatives to break down discriminatory barriers to give women a better deal, award restructuring will enable industry to open up more career paths and wider skilling opportunities for women. As I mentioned earlier, the Government has made considerable headway since 1983, not only because of the increase of 1.1 million jobs, but also because, within that increase, employment for some 600,000 women has been provided.

It is worth noting, Madam Speaker, that there are twice as many women in the work force today as there were 40 years ago. Approximately 50 per cent of the female population is now in the work force. However, there are still barriers that prevent women from participating equally. One of those barriers is job segregation, the effect of which is that approximately two-thirds of women continue to be employed in three occupational areas: the clerical area, the sales area and the service area. There is unequal access to training and career opportunities for women in the work force. Finally, lower pay is available to women in the work force. The average weekly earnings of adult women in full time employment in the work force is some 18 per cent less than that available to men.

Award restructuring can be used to redress these inequalities by removing the barriers that currently block the development of career structures and awards; by focusing attention on skill formation, which would mean increased access to training for all workers; by adjusting rates of pay on the basis of new skills; and by improving the organisation of work through job design which makes work satisfying, healthier and safer.

Let us turn to the textiles, clothing and footwear industry as an example. Of the 110,000 workers in that industry, two out of three are women. Those women occupy mainly unskilled and semi-skilled jobs. I note the specific interest in this area of the honourable member for Cowan and the effort that she has put into this effort in the past. There are award restructuring plans for the textiles, clothing and footwear industries. Under those proposals, the many job classifications in the industry are to be replaced by a small number of clearly defined job skill areas. That means that the skill and training needs for these levels will be analysed and appropriate plans will be drawn up. In the drawing up of those plans there will be involvement of the employees themselves.

The opportunities created for women are clear: there will be more career flexibility and potential, better access to training, more interesting and varied jobs and higher pay. I conclude on the note that award restructuring enables the talents of women workers to be fully used and rewarded and, when that happens, the economy as a whole will gain.

My question is addressed to the Minister for the Arts and Territories. I ask the Minister whether the former Secretary of the Aboriginal Arts Board stated recently in Townsville:

QUESTION.PARA: The Aboriginal Arts Board is in chaos today. It is directly the result of interference by Clyde Holding in the Aboriginal Arts Board.
Is it also true that on this occasion the former Secretary referred to a scam in the Aboriginal Arts Board of which the Minister was a part?

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is in order; the Minister may answer.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that I find it fascinating that, when all sorts of questions are being asked of my colleague the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and when a question is asked of me as the former Minister which suggests my involvement in a scam, there is an attempt by members of the Opposition to prevent that question being asked. Let us look at the material. What is occurring in this House is a matter of some concern to any fair-minded Australian. When any person makes any sort of allegation, whether it is true or false, if it happens to suit the political objectives of people on the Opposition side they will pick it up and run with it as if it were true and then direct questions suggesting all kinds of improprieties towards both the Minister and public servants who have served many portfolios well.

ANSWER.PARA: Let us deal with the facts. The answer to the first part of the question is yes. Mr Foley, a former Secretary of the Aboriginal Arts Board, made both those statements on the occasion of a speech to Aboriginal and Islander people in Townsville.

TALK.START.PARA: —Were you there?

—I have a copy of the text of that speech and I will be happy to make it available to the honourable gentleman. Mr Foley seems to have been adopted by the Opposition as some sort of authority. On this occasion Mr Foley also expressed his concern that his objective of turning the Townsville festival for Islander people into a major demonstration against the Bicentenary, to embarrass the Government and white people in Australia, had failed. When it comes to making allegations of this kind, it must be remembered that any person can make an allegation, but the credibility of that allegation depends on the credibility of the person making it. Mr Foley seems to have forgotten that. On this occasion he was more than hypocritical because, at the same time as he was calling on Aboriginal people around Australia to oppose all aspects of the Bicentenary, he was an applicant for a grant to the tune of $346,000 on a matter of personal concern to him-an item which was rejected out of hand and laughed out of court by the Aboriginal people who were chosen to advise on the Bicentenary, many of whom are under attack today by members of the Opposition. Let us deal with the second aspect of the question-that of the alleged scam. Mr Foley has made that allegation on a number of occasions and it relates to a perception that he had--
—Look at Barry; he's not listening to the answer. He's asleep.

—It is about time you listened to the answer. It goes back to October of 1985, or around that period, when Mr Foley came with the then President of the Aboriginal Arts Board to suggest that a public servant who had been appointed to the company known as Inada Holdings was involved in fraudulent practices. The allegations were essentially hearsay, but he said that he had it on good authority, he had a legal opinion, and he also had affidavits to support that information. I said that on that basis we would investigate it, and would he please provide the material. The matter was investigated on the basis of the hearsay allegations because the material was never produced. I table for the information of honourable members the letter sent to the President of the Aboriginal Arts Board indicating that if allegations of this kind were to be made, if there was to be any kind of substantive inquiry, there had to be proper material upon which to base those allegations.

ANSWER.PARA: Having watched the processes of this House over the last two days, I must say that what is occurring to my colleague the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs is precisely the same situation. People make an allegation but there is no written or documented proof, and he is expected to deal with it simply because the allegation is made. I table the document which indicates to the House that I sought that information from Mr Foley. It has never been forthcoming, despite the fact that he was asked. That has not stopped him elaborating on this matter even further. When he first raised it it was raised on the basis-and it was perfectly true-that I had had very little contact with the person who was appointed to this position, and it was also raised on the basis that I had had no part in his appointment. Yet on the Pru Goward Morning Show on Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) radio yesterday, Mr Foley indicated again-it is basically the same allegation-that I had been involved in fraudulent activities. He alleged corruption and said I had appointed this person, who by now had become in Mr Foley's mind a personal friend of mine. That was the substance of the allegation. It is the first time that allegation of corruption has been made in that way.

TALK.START.PARA: —This should be a personal explanation.

—The Opposition has been asking my colleague all sorts of questions. I am dealing with a serious allegation of corruption raised yesterday in the House and led by the honourable member for Menzies, who used this allegation of corruption as the basis for a major motion. But when I come to deal with this matter in a way that I think should interest honourable members, they do not want to hear about it. Why do they not want to hear about it? The person they were quoting, the person they were prepared to adopt yesterday as their authority when he resigned from the Aboriginal Arts Board, made at that time a statement in similar terms condemning this Government. When it was put to the then shadow Minister, the honourable member for Bradfield, that there was some kind of loss involved, what was his response? He said, quite frankly, that he was not sorry to see Mr Foley resign. He referred to his outlandish statements and then went on to say, quite accurately, `I cannot see how that person can be a public servant'.

ANSWER.PARA: It is a serious matter when any person is subject to smears and slander, and Mr Foley has shown himself to be an expert in that. I do not mind saying that because following a statement made on ABC radio yesterday I contacted the ABC and said clearly that the matters were defamatory and I would be taking them up. Within an hour and a half I received the following message from the ABC as the basis of a settlement:

On the ABC Pru Goward Show and the 9 a.m. ABC News of Monday, 7 November, 1988 in the course of an interview, Mr Gary Foley claimed that the former Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Clyde Holding, had suppressed allegations of corruption within the administration of Aboriginal arts when he was the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, and had also appointed a personal friend to a body concerned with Aboriginal affairs.
That is the heart of the allegation which was termed yesterday as corruption. The ABC response is simply this:
There is no evidence to support these claims and the ABC retracts the claims and apologises to Mr Holding for any embarrassment that may have been caused to him.

The costs which the ABC has paid will be donated to local Canberra charities. If there is a lesson to be learned from this matter, it is simply this: this House and the processes that exist in the community to protect individual reputations are being bandied around on a daily basis. I do not usually waste time replying to Mr Foley but when he talks about brainless black bureaucrats, abusing Aboriginal people who are serving the people of Australia well and nobly, as far as I am concerned they deserve protection just as do those non-Aboriginal public servants who have tried to promote the progress of Aboriginal people in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. We have seen in this House over the last few days an ordeal by slander. Any kind of allegation, no matter how foully based, without evidence, will be dragged in here on the basis that honourable members opposite hope that they may be able to pin it on a Minister. It is time that the Leader of the Opposition stood for some of the much vaunted principles of the rights of citizens that he talks about.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Government's failure, in priorities and policies, to address the needs of Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles Mr C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are at a stage in the administration of Aboriginal affairs which illustrates one of the most chaotic periods in that administration that this nation has ever seen. That is no better illustrated than by the fact that in the past six months there have been nine leading Aboriginal administrators sacked by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand)-eight from the Aboriginal Development Commission and the Secretary to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. That illustrates the extent of the chaos and confusion that reign within the Aboriginal affairs area. That is a great tragedy because, as most people would know and realise, the Aboriginal people are the most disadvantaged cultural group of this nation. If there is any administrative structure or any department that needs to have direction, that needs to be well planned and structured and needs to have clear goals and directions, it is the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. But today we are debating this matter of public importance because of the maladministration of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs.

SPEECH.PARA: Today I want to concentrate on two major areas. The first is the maladministration, mismanagement and lack of accountability, inertia and low morale in the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio. Apart from that there are the policy directions that this Government has set for the administration of Aboriginal affairs. We, as an Opposition, believe that these policy directions are wrong. Quite apart from what has gone on over the last week-we have had many questions asked both here and in the other House-we, as an Opposition, believe that this Government's policy directions are unsatisfactory and will not bring about a clearer, better administration for Aboriginal affairs in this nation. This bicentennial year offered an opportunity for a real movement forward in the Aboriginal affairs area, but that has not been the case. It is interesting to look at an article in the Age last week by Michelle Grattan. She said:
But the dreadful verdict, at the fag-end of party time, is hard to avoid. The opportunity has been wasted, indeed squandered. The year is ending in futility and farce.

That is what one of the leading writers in this nation is saying about the stage that has been reached in the administration of Aboriginal affairs. Why the futility and the farce? Why, having gone through 10 months of this bicentennial year, have we ended up with a farce and chaos in this administrative area?

As I have already said, the record in this area is chaotic. The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) proposal, which was to bring about a complete change in the administrative arrangement of Aboriginal affairs, has already been postponed twice. It has been put off by the Minister because he did not plan the rearrangements of this administration adequately. He did not make the judgment at the start that he could bring that sort of administrative proposal into being. So he has had to put it off, doing so under the guise that the Opposition forced him to do it or that there was a need for more consultation.

More recently we have had the case of Nardoola, which all honourable members are well aware of. I will come back to that a little later. We have had the case of the Oasis Hotel. The Charleville Housing Cooperative is another case at which we ought to have a good look. Recently we also had the Woden Town Club issue raised. We had the sacking of the Secretary to the Department just last week. Five inquiries are now being undertaken in the Aboriginal affairs area. Why do we have so many inquiries? It is because of the chaos and the Minister's handling of the Aboriginal affairs area. A Senate select committee was set up to try to ensure that the administrative arrangements which were being looked at by the Government-the ATSIC proposals-would give us some common ground; that the difficulties faced in the ATSIC proposal could be worked out; and that Aboriginal people could have a greater opportunity to make an input into the administrative arrangements of the Aboriginal affairs area. We find that when people put up different ideas to the Minister they are sacked.

A second committee of inquiry-the Senate Standing Committee of Privileges-has come about because of the way in which this matter has been handled. It is to look at the question of privilege regarding people who have been giving evidence. We also have the three government inquiries which the Minister announced yesterday. Surely the fact that we have five inquiries illustrates how important this area is and how much chaos exists within the Aboriginal affairs area. The Government knows it and it is trying to stonewall with these three government inquiries-and Auditor-General's inquiry, an inquiry by a member of the Public Service Commission and an inquiry to be conducted by Mr Menzies in case something else comes out of the woodwork on the way through. All of these inquiries are virtually internal inquiries; they are not inquiries in which people will have privilege.

The Government's approach in this area has been one of separate development of Aboriginals in Australia. That approach may have been appropriate at a certain stage in Australia's history. I say that because it serves to highlight at a particular time the disadvantages of Aboriginal people in this nation. It was necessary to develop a community awareness; it was necessary to look at it as a separate issue, a separate department and a separate bureaucracy so that the nation would understand and come to appreciate more fully the difficulties faced by Aboriginal people in this nation.

I put it to the House that that era is long passed. The coalition recognises that Aboriginal people should be able to choose their traditional lifestyles or enter into more mainstream living within the Australian community. The coalition also recognises that the Government's policy and its focus in this area have led to isolation and could lead to a ghetto situation for many Aboriginal people. Separate development by the Government has led to a very impressionistic approach to its policy. Its policy is blurred.

The Government, by setting agendas and moods, is not really addressing the hard issues of Aboriginal affairs. That is no better illustrated than by the cartoon in today's Australian, which really encapsulates the Government's mood. In this cartoon the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is shown sitting at his desk and the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs is shown sitting in a chair in the Prime Minister's office, with the Prime Minister saying:
Crumbs, Gerry-I'da sworn our Aboriginal policies were vague enough to never hafta make a decision about anything!
That describes very clearly that the Government's policies are so vague, so poorly organised, so poorly directed and so poorly worked.

The Government's concept of separate development will not work and the structures adopted are ones that in the long term, because of these arrangements, will hinder the alleviation of disadvantage, the inefficiency, the cronyism and the deals within the Aboriginal affairs area. That is why we are debating this issue today. Only today the Minister indicated at a press conference that even the proposal to reorganise Aboriginal affairs would be modified. This Minister's proposal which, as he has said in earlier debates about this matter, is of great significance and importance to Australian people, will now be modified. In other words, the Government realises that its proposal is not adequate and it is backing off. There is no rationale for the ATSIC proposal and there is no evidence that if this new administrative structure were implemented it would prevent the Nardoolas occurring; that it would prevent the Woden Town Club issues arising; and that it would prevent the Oasis issue from coming to the forepoint. What about the missing funds in regard to Boomanulla Oval at Narrabundah?

The Government's backing off is symptomatic of the vague and impressionistic approach that the Minister has adopted to Aboriginal affairs. Why has the Minister not given us any legal opinion on the preamble to the ATSIC proposal? It is an issue which raises the antecedent title of this nation and the issue of sovereignty, yet the Government and the Minister have failed to give us any policy direction in that matter. That muddled approach to their thinking is indicated in that latest report which was brought into the House just last week. People will remember a debate and a resolution on Aboriginal affairs which took place in this House only a few weeks ago. The coalition sought to insert in that resolution the words `in common with all other Australians'. When we got the interim report on the effectiveness of support services throughout Aboriginal and Torres Strait Island communities, we found the Department of Aboriginal Affairs saying exactly that:
The determination was based on the recognition of the equal rights of Aboriginal people, along with other Australians, to determine their own future within the Australian community.

We find that the Government does not really know where it is going in Aboriginal affairs. As a consequence of this Government's misdirected policy, its misdirected priorities and its interest only in superficial things, the administrative task-the hard area-has not been addressed. The Minister and the Department have not focused their attention on the key issues that affect Aboriginal people. Matters such as health, housing, education and unemployment have already been mentioned here today. The Government should be focusing on and giving attention to these areas.

Let us just return to what happened with the Woden Town Club. The Minister knew about the proposal to purchase the poker machines. Why did it take five months for him to respond and to say that he would do something about it? In case after case we find that the Government has not attended to the issues which affect the people because it has been chasing hares, chasing issues which, for the Aboriginal people, mean very little.

The Minister knows that the Aboriginals of this nation are faced with many issues. I appreciate that this area of administration is very complex and difficult. But we have had a situation in which the leading administrators in Aboriginal affairs have been sacked. The Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) commissioners who were sacked were not given any reasons for their sacking or any explanations as to why they were sacked. Last week, the Secretary to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs was sacked. The area of Aboriginal affairs has been allocated over $808m. Where is all that money going? Is it getting to the grass roots? Obviously it is not. The issues which we have raised in the Parliament over the last week or so illustrate so many instances where money is not getting to the people and is not being directed to those issues of priority for Aboriginal people.

TALK.START.PARA: -Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hand The Hon G.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the second day on which this debate has been attempted. It has to be said right from the outset that we have again heard a broad brush approach to matters dealing with Aboriginal affairs. We have heard slick, meaningless words. Some of the inferences are totally untrue. Again the Opposition is continuing the massive slur that it is trying to portray from that side of the House. For nearly two months now we have heard these slurs and innuendos being made about a whole range of individuals, designed purely to turn the non-Aboriginal community off the Aboriginal community.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us analyse what the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles) said. He talked about Nardoola-bought by the Opposition. When the Opposition was in government it set up the legislation for the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC), and the senator who has been slamming hell out of the ADC for the last four to five weeks congratulated the ADC on its report-the very report that he is attacking now. The employees of the ADC, the employees of my Department, and the Aboriginal community deserve better. They deserve better than what that lot has given them. I have said all along-and this is the first time I have had a chance to say it here-that I will investigate and have investigated every irregularity that is brought to my attention. We have set up a mechanism to do that, and I remind the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown) of what he said once before. He said, `The Government will look at this and the Government will take action'.

TALK.START.PARA: —On what issues?
—On not needing a royal commission on a particular matter. In a speech in the House he said:

SPEECH.PARA: There are obviously imperfections in the words of the Perth office of the Crown Solicitor's Office and the Government will take action.
There was action. In this case, to use the honourable member's words, we are taking action. In terms of Nardoola, I will first address--

TALK.START.PARA: —You got a bit confused there, Gerry.

—I am not confused; I am trying to make a point about what the honourable member did not do about royal commissions. I could go on about that, too. The questions that have been raised cover the years 1980, 1981, 1982, 1983, 1984 and 1985. The Opposition talks about the protection of people. We had an inquiry into the ADC in 1984 and 1985. People appeared before that inquiry and gave evidence in camera. Now we have the spectacle of the Opposition wanting that information disclosed to gain cheap political points. People appeared before that inquiry knowing it was going to be in camera. Is that fair? Is it proper that people should come here before a parliamentary committee to disclose matters about certain issues under the protection of the Parliament, under the protection of the Committee, in camera, and then have this phony argument trotted out here that we should make it public? That is not fair.

SPEECH.PARA: We have attempted to set up a series of mechanisms. Let us consider the number of inquiries that are taking place and scrape away the facade. Why was the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs set up? It was set up to delay the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) legislation, and everybody knows that is why the Opposition insisted on its establishment. The Opposition has not got the guts to go out and vote it down. That is what is wrong with that lot over there. Opposition members have not got the guts to go out and vote it down. I said on 10 December that I would give as much time as was required by Aboriginal people. I said that, if need be, we would extend the amount of time that was available. I have done that. I went back to those who requested that we go back. We sent back their changes and we came back and changed the ATSIC legislation. But the interesting thing about this mob of gooses over there, this commission over there, the people who want to do nothing--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about a commissioner for Palm Island?

—I will come to the honourable member's policy. The Opposition's position goes something like this: we will delay it because it will never ever happen. But not one suggested change to legislation has come out of the Liberal and National parties-not one word, not one suggestion about how to change it. Why? Because Opposition members do not want the damned legislation. That is why, and they do not have the guts to get up and vote it down. These people opposite have one policy, and that is to mainstream Aboriginal affairs and hand them back to the States-hand them back to the States that have crucified and slaughtered Aboriginal people since the States first came into existence.
—Nonsense.

—The honourable member knows that is right, and the only hope the Aboriginal people have is this Federal Parliament. We cannot have the States running a whole series of policies. That will not work. But that is the Opposition's policy. Its policy is to hand Aboriginal affairs back to the States and mainstream them. That is why this bloke, the honourable member for Braddon, went overseas. Having launched his policy, he ran away. I think it is the only Opposition policy launch that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) has not turned up to. I was not there, but I am told that is true. The honourable member for Braddon shot off overseas, out of the road. His Leader then went up to the Pitjantjatjara people and they just about ran him off their land. They called him a little boy. If Opposition members had not gone up there to get their photo taken with some Aboriginal people but had sat down with the people and said, `Tell us what is wrong', they might have got a different response. But they went up there to exploit a situation and they came a gutser. That is what happened in Ernabella. Yet these people opposite talk about what they did.

SPEECH.PARA: I have said here before that there are problems that need addressing, and Aboriginal people know there are problems that need addressing. But those opposite do not want to help fix those problems. I do not know how many times I have said to the honourable member for Braddon, `Why don't we try to work on these things together?' We could work together on the parliamentary Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs. We could come up with solutions about town camps, legal aid and services to Aboriginal people. I know that; I was chairman of that Committee. We could sit down and talk about it. God help me, I shared a tent with the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron). It was a risk-I lasted only one night-but that committee had some worthwhile results. That was applauded by Aboriginal people, and we worked together. But we cannot work with the honourable member for Braddon because he does not want that to happen. This person produces policies which he knows are not in the interests of Aboriginal people, and then he runs off on an overseas jaunt as soon as he has dropped his policy on the table. I have had enough of his pious nonsense. The Opposition has set out through the other place to denigrate and destroy persons, in fact destroy a whole race of people, through backhanders and accusations for which it has no damned proof.

TALK.START.PARA: —You sacked them.
—There is no proof at all. Those opposite have to be looked at.
—Why did you sack them?
—I warn the honourable member for Braddon.

—If the honourable member brings these problem areas forward, I will investigate them. I said that right at the beginning. The honourable member has not brought too many to me; that is one thing I know. Maybe he is overseas more than I know, or maybe he does not talk to many Aboriginals. If he has any problems that he wants addressed, I will look at them. I give him that commitment. I give that commitment to the House again because what is happening in this country today is grossly unfair. The slightest thing can be said about anybody, particularly if that person is an Aboriginal or a member of a minority group, and it can be unfairly splashed across the front page of every newspaper. No facts are checked and there is no information given other than that somebody has said it. What happens? We have to have a royal commission. This just has to stop. I make this plea to members of the Opposition: for God's sake, before you wreck the whole show can you not, with us, work out an orderly way to address this situation?
—Always willing.

—The honourable member says they are always willing. They have been so willing in the last month or so that they have dragged out matters that their Minister was responsible for and who said himself, when in office, that the legislation did not allow him to take a particular course of action. I tried to change that. I tried to bring in Aboriginal people, which those opposite said ought to happen. We had a debate on this while the honourable member was overseas. But where is the legislation? It is sitting on the table in the other place and we cannot move. It is just sitting there.
—We aren't the Government.

—Honourable members opposite are the Opposition, and they will not let it happen in the Senate. They know that, and the Aboriginal people have to wake up to who is the villain here. The legislation is sitting over there and the Opposition has put a blocker on it because it does not want the Aboriginal people to have a say. Opposition members want to consult with them, they want to take their clipboards out and write down what they think, but then they go away and do what they want to do. I am saying that that has to change. Aboriginal people have to have a say. If they do not have a say the policies will not work. The honourable member for Braddon should talk to the last Liberal Minister for Aboriginal Affairs-and God help us if the honourable member ever got this job-because if he talked to the people in his Party who were members of the Ministry they will say, in agreeing with me and with the Committee we served on, that the one thing the Aboriginal people said they were sick to death of was people coming around with clipboards. In one community in the Anangu Pitjantjatjara lands, nine different sets of clipboards were seen in one day and 40 different departmental officers visited in one week. How the hell is anything supposed to work effectively with that sort of organisation? The Opposition's actions are all about stopping change taking place to involve Aboriginal people.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to raise one or two other points in the couple of minutes I have left. I ask people to look at what happened when those opposite were in office and what has happened since; to look at the change in direction, the change in expenditure, the change in the development of programs and at the greater number of people of Aboriginal descent who are involved in those programs. Some of the programs put in place by the Opposition have been expanded and developed, and those programs are to be applauded. But members of the Opposition do not say that. Everything that we have tried to do is wrong, and has to be smashed down. That is the Opposition's policy under the honourable member for Braddon. I wish the Leader of the Opposition would get rid of him. I wish he had rung the right bloke and got rid of the honourable member for Braddon like he was trying to do, instead of getting rid of that other poor person. We would be a lot better off.

This matter of public importance is a sham. It is a sham because Opposition members do not believe it. They have exploited this situation and whipped up a frenzy. Senator Tambling has made claims about a black mafia but when challenged as to why he said it, what did he say? He said, `I used the term ``black mafia'' to attract a bit of media attention'. For God's sake, what decent person in this place believes that to be fair? Why should a whole race of people be subjected to this sort of nonsense without one Opposition member of this House saying to the Aboriginal community, `I dissociate myself from Senator Tambling'? Not one honourable member opposite did that. Accusation after accusation has been made. We have a chance in this nation if we work together. I will talk to any member of the Opposition about any problem if that member wants to talk to me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —All of the huffing and puffing by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) and his abuse and criticism of the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles), and other Opposition members is no answer to the current problems facing Aboriginal people. I support the raising of this matter of public importance because of the scandalous administration of Aboriginal affairs and the blatant waste of taxpayers' money for little or no benefit to the bulk of Aboriginal people.
—It didn't happen under me.

—I will talk about our performance later. I represent in the electorate of Gwydir one of the largest Aboriginal populations in New South Wales and, indeed, in eastern Australia. For years I have been sickened by the campaigns sponsored by some radical white activists, political opportunists and some opportunistic lawyers in the Aboriginal legal aid organisations, in the pursuit of land rights where there is no traditional affinity, especially outside the Northern Territory, who have sought funds for Aboriginal enterprises which have no hope of success. While these crazy objectives are being pursued and have been pursued over a period, inadequate funds have been provided for decent housing, education and job training for Aboriginal youth and health services.

SPEECH.PARA: Heaven knows, some very substantial budgets have been allocated by the Fraser and Hawke governments over recent years. But nowhere is the problem more publicly evident than in Toomelah near the Queensland border. The commission of inquiry into the Toomelah community exposed the disastrous lack of coordination and cooperation between the various arms of government. In spite of local demands for adequate housing, water, sewerage and other services which are available to most white communities, the pleas of the Toomelah people were ignored until violence flared in Goondiwindi. People living in abject poverty and squalor are not interested in the rights or wrongs of land rights, Aboriginal enterprises, treaties and the fantasies of Ministers and administrators. All they seek is a fair go and equal rights with other fellow Australians.

Toomelah is but one example of what is going on in this country. Many Aboriginal communities have worse living conditions than Toomelah. The Namoi Reserve on the banks of the Namoi River, three kilometres from Walgett, is a case in point. The living conditions of Aboriginal Australians at the Namoi Reserve are an international human disgrace. Who are we to wave our fingers at South Africa when we allow our fellow countrymen, women and children to suffer under such appalling conditions? I say that with some feeling.

I believe the establishment of the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) has been a mistake. It was our Government that established it. But that does not excuse the recent and current Ministers from responsibility for the wastage that has occurred since 1983. Hundreds of millions of dollars have been wasted in the purchase of properties, hotels and enterprises which stand as monuments to the condemnation of the Aboriginal Development Commission, the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the responsible Ministers. How many administrative disasters do the Aboriginal people have to suffer with humiliation? They are the people who suffer the most humiliation when they fail. How many of these projects must fail before we go back to basics and assess with the Aboriginal people the priorities of their needs? I think that the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs needed to be set up to examine the concerns about and allegations of wastage that have been about for some time.

Let us look at the two other disastrous investments in the electorate of Gwydir. They have been mentioned many times. The purchase of Nardoola near Moree by the ADC was made, as the Minister has said, during the period of the former Fraser Government. It was purchased for $585,132. On whose valuation was the purchase incurred? Apparently, it was on the valuation of the Australian Taxation Office and the Valuer-General. At the time the local people and local valuers were amazed and astounded at the purchase price. Commercial viability was a secondary consideration. The overriding consideration at that time was the potential value to the Aboriginal community as a social resource. Between 1981-82 and 1986-87 $812,357 was poured into this social resource. This amount does not include taxpayers funds from other sources such as the Commonwealth community employment program and the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations. Although statements were prepared by local Moree auditors, they were not signed by the directors of the Nardoola Aboriginal Corporation. Why?

In the five years from 1 July 1982 until the year ended June 1987, the gross return from this $812,357 outlay was no more than $44,079. During those years the home on the property was burnt down, fencing materials were stolen, livestock and wool were alleged to have been stolen, and the property fell into total disrepair and was valued at $261,725 in March 1986. Now, the Minister tells us, in reply to my question on notice, which has been on the Notice Paper for 12 months, that `as the property was purchased for economic and social purposes, calculation of a net loss can only be notional.' I say to him: What rubbish! There is little interest locally in Nardoola among the Aboriginal people. Most Aboriginal people in Moree want better living conditions and see Nardoola as a costly waste of money when their friends and relatives are living in shocking conditions at Toomelah and elsewhere.

The other notable example of the irresponsibility of the Aboriginal Development Commission was the purchase of the now well publicised Oasis Hotel on 14 November 1983. The Minister has indicated that the total cost, including the purchase price and further grants, amounted to $842,446, but no information is available to ascertain trading losses of that business because of so-called commercial secrecy. This hotel was handed over to an incorporated Aboriginal association called Gamilarai Ltd. This unfortunate association is now in difficulties because not all of its creditors have been paid. The ADC is owed money for outstanding loans, but the loans have been suspended until the Oasis is leased out which, hopefully, will enable it to trade itself out of difficulty.

The hotel was purchased to create an economically viable business enterprise to provide job training but the venture was badly thought through by the Commission and the Government. Today, that hotel stands locked, barred up and closed and is another humiliation to the Aboriginal people. I do not blame the Aboriginal people; I blame the Aboriginal Development Commission, the Minister and the Government for allowing this disgraceful state of affairs to occur. I also mention one other matter: the incredible circumstances surrounding Trekka Aboriginal Arts and Craft Ltd and the way in which Margaret Valadian and Natasha McNamara have been treated by Minister Holding and some officers of his Department. I am pleased to note that the Minister will refer this case to the inquiry.

The Government has failed the Aboriginal people because it has failed to establish priorities of needs. Aboriginal people generally have been the humiliated victims of maladministration, mismanagement and lack of accountability by successive Ministers of this Government. The desperate and glaring needs of the Aboriginal people have been overshadowed by promises of land rights; promises of a vague treaty; and promises of theoretical and academic solutions and salvation. The Aboriginal people are the victims of clumsy social experiments conducted by dreamy academics and bureaucrats and stupid Ministers who are often deep in some philosophical dreamtime.

There is chaos in the administration of Aboriginal affairs and policy directions. Unfortunately, the inquiry could well fail because it is not a full, independent, judicial inquiry which I believe is necessary to bring about the changes which I am sure the Minister would want to see. The fact is that most Aboriginals are desperately trying to get into the mainstream of modern society as an ethnic group with every reason to be proud of their race. So, for goodness sake, let us get back to basics. Aboriginal people need help in the fields of housing, education, job training and health. I ask the Government to go back to the drawing board and deliver some basic human requirements to the Aboriginal people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snowdon Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House for the opportunity to speak in this debate.
—We do too.

—I am sure the honourable member does not because he might learn something that he does not like. What I will seek to demonstrate during my contribution is the callous and contradictory way in which the Opposition has dealt with the matter of Aboriginal affairs. I point out to the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) that Nardoola was bought under a Liberal-National Party administration. The Opposition bought it during its administration. I would have thought that the honourable member for Gwydir, as a person who has been in this House such a long time, a senior member of this House, would have thought it appropriate to mention to the House that this Government, along with the New South Wales Government, has moved to rectify the situation at Toomelah. But oh, no! The Opposition has continued its vitriolic campaign, epitomised now by the honourable member for Gwydir-a person I have great respect for-coming into this House and making comments which deride the truth. He knows they deride the truth. Not only that; he knows that at the Namoi reserve which he referred to there is now a two-year program in place to rectify the situation there. But he chose not to tell the House. He is pursuing, and has pursued in his contribution here today, the same sort of course that has been sought by the Opposition since this Government was re-elected last year.

SPEECH.PARA: The Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) is a creature of the Opposition, as we well know. I point out what Senator Chaney said in his second reading speech about the ADC on 5 March 1980. I hope the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles) talks to Senator Chaney. He might teach the honourable member about respect for Aboriginal people and respect for the terms `self-determination' and `self-management'. They are things which the honourable member for Braddon, who is at the table, would not have a clue about. Minister Chaney said:
It is the first time that a departmental function has been handed over to a commission in the way that is now proposed with the enterprise function of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs.
I can assure the Senate that the Aboriginal Development Commission Bill is consistent with the Government's policy of self-management.

That has gone out the window. The Opposition has given it the boot, shafted it, flick-passed it somewhere else. It is no longer interested in the propositions of self-management and self-determination. I will demonstrate that very shortly. First, I refer a little further to Senator Chaney's speech. He said:

All honourable senators should take some pleasure in that because all honourable senators who were here some years ago voted for the motion that Senator Bonner moved in this place seeking that recognition. Therefore, I believe that we should welcome this legislation which follows the resolution supported by all parts of this chamber.
What was former Senator Bonner's resolution? I remind honourable members opposite in the context of their contributions here today. This is what Senator Bonner moved in his motion:

That the Senate accepts the fact that the indigenous people of Australia, now known as Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders, were in possession of this entire nation prior to the 1788 First Fleet landing at Botany Bay, urges the Australian Government to admit prior ownership by the said indigenous people, and introduce legislation to compensate the people now known as Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders for dispossession of their land.

We know what has happened. The Opposition has adopted a cynical course of action which has sought to vilify Aboriginal people in recent weeks. More importantly, since this Government was returned to power last year, the Opposition has embarked on a course to divide this country. It has embarked on this course to divide the country along racial lines. We have seen it in two debates. We have seen it in the immigration debate and now we are seeing it again in the Aboriginal affairs debate. On three occasions we have come into this place and invited the Opposition to come with us, to join in a reconciliation, to join with Aboriginal people, and come to terms with the contemporary realities. But it has refused. It has refused to support the bipartisan statement suggested to this chamber by the churches. It has refused to support the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) proposal even though it knows full well what its merits are. It has refused to support the treaty proposition even though its worth is tacitly recognised by Senator Bonner's motion in the Senate. That is what the Opposition is up to.

In the five minutes I have left I want to have a go at the Opposition's policy because I know what its policy stands for. I know that not many members of the Opposition have read it. I wonder whether the Opposition spokesman for Aboriginal affairs, the honourable member for Braddon, has read it. It is in contrast to what was a very well-meaning policy put forward by the Opposition when it was in government about land rights, self-determination, self-management and all of those things that Aboriginal people around this country still desire-contrary to what the Opposition might think and particularly what the honourable member for Gwydir thought. It seems to me that what the honourable member for Gwydir was saying when he said he wanted the ADC knocked off was that he believes that Aboriginal people should no longer have the right to self-determination and self-management.

I reject that proposition. This Government rejects this proposition. It is something the honourable member for Gwydir should think about because what he is proposing reflects a sanctimonious and patronising attitude. The honourable member for Gwydir has decided this in his wisdom, helped by his crony Senator Tambling, the mug from the north, who has previously in the Senate said how much he supported land rights and ATSIC. Let me tell the House about his support of ATSIC. Senator Tambling said on 27 April 1988:

I certainly agree with Senator Chaney and Senator Collins that in the past few months the Minister has been hard at work in a very elaborate, detailed and genuine consultative process around the community . . . I do accept that the Government has embarked on a very meaningful consultation process. From my experience, and that of Senator Collins, in the Northern Territory we can certainly appreciate the efforts of the Minister and the Department of Aboriginal Affairs.

Now what do we have? We have a witch-hunt. The star chamber, the Senate Estimates Committee, is being used to slur the names of Aboriginal people throughout this country and undermine the wider community support for the concept of Aboriginal self-management and self-determination.

This Government is addressing those issues. This Government has sought to remedy the problems the Opposition thinks it has identified in the ATSIC proposal. Yet the Opposition has sought to undermine the Government's objectives. The Opposition has sought to ensure that the ATSIC proposal is not enacted. And now it has been successful in frustrating the ambitions of this House. The Opposition has been successful in having the clowns in the Senate doing what they do best-using leaked documents which come directly from organisations under this Government in order to ask 400 questions. I think that is the number Senator Tambling has asked. Senator Tambling would not know what the questions meant. He would not have had the intelligence to put them together. Yet he has used them. The questions did not come from him, and what is more he would not know what they meant.

Let me tell honourable members about the Opposition's policy. I will use a few short, precise words to define the Opposition's policy. It is paternalistic; it is assimilationist; it treats Aboriginal people with contempt; it undermines self-determination and self-management for Aboriginal people; it attacks the very basis of the land rights Act in the Northern Territory. The Opposition views Aboriginal people as an indigenous people with a dead culture. It hijacks Australian Labor Party policy. The only good thing in the Opposition policy is this:
encourage the establishment of enterprises run by Aboriginal people, support AEDP, support CDEP, employ people in national parks.
This Government has activated those policies. The Opposition should not come in here and bleat in support of a parsimonious matter of public importance in these terms:
The Government's failure, in priorities and policies, to address the needs of Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders.

Opposition members know that is not true. Let me conclude by saying that a couple of weeks ago that good Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), went to central Australia to visit some Aboriginal people near Ernabella. He and Senator Tambling both accused Aboriginal people of being orchestrated by the Minister. In fact, Senator Tambling in an interview on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation program Territory Extra on 7 November 1988 said:
. . . Charlie Perkins is crying crocodile tears. But it's really Hand that is the racist in this whole issue.
He was asked why Mr Hand was racist. He said:

The best example I can give you of that is, about a week ago, John Howard went to Ernabella in South Australia, and it was a pre-organised trip and it was to go in and genuinely find out was was going, going, just going on there. And what does Gerry Hand do, he walks in the day before, and sets the whole scene. . .
Well, I'll be! He went on:
. . . and sets it up and we find Aboriginal people standing up with pre-prepared press releases nicely duplicated, you know, criticising John Howard for a whole range of things.

Why would they not criticise the Leader of the Opposition? He is a clown. He has gone out there and expected Aboriginals to bite the tripe that he gives them. What was Yami Lester's response to this sort of sanctimonious approach?
