SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee Mr M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The legislation before the House, the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill, gives effect to the major recommendations made to the Government by the Veterans' Entitlements Act Monitoring Committee. As honourable members would be aware, that very important Committee was established by this Government on 18 May 1987 under the chairmanship of Justice Paul Toose. The Monitoring Committee was established after the Parliament passed the Veterans' Entitlements Act, which made major changes to the legislation which governs the payments to veterans. I understand that the Government, under the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys), has already announced that it will accept 28 of the Monitoring Committee's recommendations in full and another four recommendations in a modified form. I commend the Minister and the Government for speedily agreeing to and endorsing publicly those recommendations. The legislation before the House addresses nine of the Monitoring Committee's recommendations.

SPEECH.PARA: We should recognise that payments to veterans are compensation, and not welfare. They are compensation to veterans for service given to their country in time of war. I hope that all honourable members would endorse that comment. I certainly do. The first recommendation put forward by the Monitoring Committee was for the payment of an additional allowance to retired veterans who are severely incapacitated. I commend the Minister for speedily agreeing to the establishment of a new allowance called the extreme disablement adjustment (EDA). This new allowance will be paid to frail, aged veterans who currently receive the 100 per cent disability payment and are, in addition, severely incapacitated due to war-caused injuries.

Mr Deputy Speaker, as you would be aware, there are now many veterans who are severely incapacitated but who are past the normal age of retirement and cannot receive the totally and permanently incapacitated (TPI) rate of payment. At the suggestion of the Monitoring Committee, the Minister has agreed that these veterans should now receive the extreme disablement adjustment, which, in effect, will give them a total of 150 per cent of the maximum general rate, that is, their existing 100 per cent plus the EDA allowance. For someone who qualifies for this new adjustment allowance, it will mean an increase in the amount that person receives from $84.30 a week in disability pension to a total of $126.45 a week in disability pension plus the extreme disablement adjustment. That certainly is something which I am sure will be welcomed by those frail, aged veterans who are incapacitated and who could do with that money. The payment is tax free at the moment and will remain tax free under this Government.

Having heard the speech made last night by the shadow Minister for veterans' affairs, the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer), I imagine that Opposition speakers later in this debate will say, `That is fine, but you are the government that is responsible for tightening the rules for TPIs'. That is the argument we heard last night. The questions I put to Opposition members are: Would they, if they were in government, overturn the changes which were made in 1985? Would they expand and loosen the definitions of eligibility for TPIs? I am getting a little tired of hearing Opposition members claim that this Government is the government that is responsible for tightening the eligibility rules for TPIs. I remind the House that Liberal and National Party senators voted with Labor Party senators at the time to tighten the rules for TPI eligibility.

The Opposition has recently released for the next election its policy on veterans' affairs. I hold that policy in my hand, and nowhere in it is there any promise to allow veterans who used to qualify for the TPI pension to again receive the TPI pension. I ask Opposition members: Are they telling us that they will remove the requirement that people still be receiving a remuneration when applying for the TPI pension? We have nothing from the Opposition, certainly not in this policy document, to suggest that it will change the rules.

Another matter addressed in this legislation is a relaxation of the eligibility requirements which currently exist for the special and intermediate rate TPI pensions. At the moment veterans have to receive a 100 per cent disability pension as a first requirement before they can be awarded the TPI rate. The Government has sensibly agreed to relax that eligibility requirement from 100 per cent to only 70 per cent. That will make a considerable difference to those veterans trying to receive a TPI pension. One other matter addressed in the legislation concerns the controversial issue of the fixed application date of assessment. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs, in his second reading speech, said:

The Committee cited the example of a veteran who is employed at the time when his or her claim is lodged, who expects to and who subsequently does retire due to war-caused disabilities before the claim is determined. This veteran would not be required under the new scheme to lodge a fresh application upon retirement. Such a person will be entitled to special rate pension for life, provided of course that all the eligibility criteria continue to be satisfied in all respects at the date of his or her retirement.

The important point to note is that there has been some concern expressed by the veteran community. Some subbranches of the Returned Services League in my electorate have been very concerned that some of the determining authorities within the Repatriation Commission are strictly looking only at a person's eligibility at the date of application. I know that the Minister has received some correspondence on this matter, and I am pleased that he has speedily introduced legislation which clarifies this issue, which has been causing some concern amongst veterans in my electorate. It perhaps would have been better if this issue had not arisen in the way that it has. But since the problem has been raised by veterans, I am pleased that the Minister, through these amendments, is making it very clear that veterans will not be penalised if their war-caused injuries deteriorate after the date of application.

Another issue I wish to raise this afternoon is that of legal aid for veterans. The Veterans' Entitlements Act is a very complex piece of legislation because it covers complex issues. One would have to go a long way to find a veteran who had the capacity and the legal training to understand all of the requirements of the Veterans' Entitlements Act. Therefore, it is very important that veterans have the right to obtain expert legal advice on matters which affect their eligibility for service pensions, for disability pensions, and for other entitlements. It is very important that they be able to receive good quality legal advice. I am embarrassed to say to the House that the Liberal and National Party State Government of New South Wales under Mr Nick Greiner has not yet taken any action to overturn a decision of the Legal Aid Commission of New South Wales to take away from veterans in New South Wales their automatic right to obtain legal advice on matters affecting repatriation. When veterans came to see me about complex veterans' affairs issues it was a great advantage for me to be able to say to them, `This is what you should do, but speak to the solicitor at legal aid who is the expert on veterans' affairs issues and he will ensure that you have expert and up to date advice'. I cannot say that to my veterans any more, because a means test is now applied in New South Wales to veterans who ask for legal aid. Before the Greiner Government's Legal Aid Commission took this decision, New South Wales veterans could obtain that expert legal advice on repatriation matters without having to satisfy a means test. Now New South Wales veterans, because of the decision by the Legal Aid Commission of New South Wales, have to satisfy a very tight and strict means test. Many veterans in my electorate, and throughout New South Wales, cannot now get the legal advice they need, because of the decision by the State independent authority. I have raised this matter with the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate). I know he has written to the New South Wales Attorney-General, Mr Dowd. I am embarrassed to say that the Liberal Party still has not taken any action on this issue. New South Wales veterans have been writing to Mr Dowd. They have been raising the issue. I am embarrassed to say that that Government does not care enough about New South Wales veterans to get Mr Dowd to overturn that decision. I hope that perhaps some Liberal Party and National Party members in this chamber could approach Mr Dowd and get him to take some quick action on this issue.

Another issue which needs to be addressed in this debate is another recommendation put forward by the Monitoring Committee on the Veterans' Entitlements Act. I understand that the Committee has put forward a proposal to replace the Veterans Review Board (VRB). It has put forward a proposal to abolish the three-member Veterans Review Board and replace it with a single delegate of the Commission. I have been advised by a member of Brisbane Waters Legacy in my electorate that, at the recent national conference of the Legacy organisation, the various subbranches and clubs of Legacy unanimously voted to oppose the Monitoring Committee's suggestion of replacing the VRB with a single delegate of the Commission. My own view is that it would be a backward step to replace a three-member Veterans Review Board with a single delegate of the Commission. We have to accept that the first level decision is made by a delegate; and that is a single person. If we have another single person hearing appeals, there is a chance that people will not get as fair a deal as they are now getting under the three-member Veterans Review Board.

The last thing I wish to touch on is the policy which has been released by the Liberal and National parties for the next election on veterans' affairs issues. I believe it is in order to so so because of the nature of the amendment that has been moved by the honourable member for Farrer, the shadow Minister for veterans' affairs. The honourable member's amendment lists many areas in which veterans have been treated harshly by this Government. He made the claim last night that this Government had made severe cutbacks in veterans' affairs. I will cite one figure to the honourable member for Farrer and other Opposition members who continue to peddle the line that veterans' affairs have suffered massive cutbacks. The Liberal and National Party Government spent $1,323m on veterans' affairs in 1981-82, its last full financial year. This year this Government will spend $3.2 billion on veterans' affairs issues. That is an increase from $1.3 billion to $3.2 billion. I know that inflation has eroded the value of the dollar, but I have taken the trouble to adjust these figures for that effect. If we convert everything into today's dollars so that we have discounted the effect of inflation, we will see that in 1981-82, in today's dollars, the Liberal-National Party Government spent $2.1 billion on veterans; today, using dollars of the same value, we have increased that to $3.2 billion-almost a 50 per cent increase in real terms. Yes, the average age of veterans has increased during that period, but certainly not enough to account for a 50 per cent increase in real terms. I wish the Opposition would not keep trying to create some form of fear in the electorate by making outrageous claims that somehow or other there have been phenomenal cuts in veterans' affairs funding, because that is just not true.

The honourable member for Farrer, the shadow Minister, listed a whole series of areas where he thought the Government had done the wrong thing. One of the areas in which he claimed it has done the wrong thing is on the question of changes made in 1986 under the Veterans' Entitlements Act. Here I quote two paragraphs from the Liberal Party's veterans' affairs policy:
There are a number of areas of concern arising from the Veterans' Entitlements Act including the tightening up of Totally and Permanently Incapacitated Pensions criteria.
The Liberal and National Parties will remove anomalies and forms of discrimination on the grounds of a Veterans' gender, such as discrimination against widower of Ex-Servicewomen.

No promise is made there to overturn the changes made in 1986, as the honourable member for Farrer often tries to imply in this House. Another part of the Liberal Party policy headed, `Disability Pensions and Other Benefits', states:

The Liberal and National Parties in Government will continue to provide for the 100% Disability Pension, Intermediate Rate Totally and Permanently Incapacitated Pension and Special Rate Totally and Permanently Incapacitated Pension with one notable additional provision.

And the policy goes on simply to explain that this great new alteration to the policy, the one change it will make, is the payment of an extreme disability adjustment-a provision already included in this Bill.

So where is the great change? Where are the great things that the Liberal and National parties are promising for veterans? They are certainly not in the Liberal Party policy, because the one major promise in the policy is met by this Bill-the extreme disablement adjustment allowance. So I suggest to veterans that every time a member of the Opposition goes round to a Returned Services League club or to an RSL subbranch and seeks to suggest to them that if only the coalition were in government veterans who now receive only a service pension would suddenly be eligible for a TPI pension, they question those members closely because those veterans know in their heart of hearts that a coalition government would not change the eligibility rules for TPI pensions.

The Opposition will not suddenly relax the criteria for TPI pensions, and veterans know that, but Opposition members do not have the guts and the honesty to be frank with veterans and tell them the real situation. They are counting on veterans not being able to get hold of a copy of the policy and they are counting on the fact that they will be able to have this policy in their back pocket. Tell veterans anything they like in private, and veterans will never be able to compare what is said to them, verbally, with what is written down in their policy because the policy is riddled with qualifications which will mean that veterans really get nothing from the Opposition.

Listen to some of the phrases the Opposition uses: `when economic resources permit', `as resources permit', `we'll do all we can', `we'll do everything the responsible government can afford'. With all of these qualifications, the truth is that the Opposition is promising absolutely nothing for veterans.

TALK.START.PARA: —`When they can afford it'!
—And as the Minister for Veterans' Affairs suggests, there is the other qualification of `when they can afford it'.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting that the shadow Minister for finance, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), is sitting at the table at the moment because I am sure he will do all in his power to ensure that the Opposition's policies will not allow any promises to veterans which will help them improve their position.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Andrew?

—As the Minister suggests, the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), will also ensure that less money is available for veterans' affairs. As they go around the traps, Opposition members are saying that governments spend too much money. They are saying that even the Business Council of Australia's proposal to abolish the Department of Veterans' Affairs was too weak; it did not go far enough. That remark is on the record from the shadow Treasurer-that a proposal to abolish the Department of Veterans' Affairs did not go far enough, did not cut back government spending enough. Where does that leave the veterans? The Minister for Veterans' Affairs is concerned about veterans.
—A great Minister!

—He is a great Minister, as the honourable member for Parramatta interjects. He is a Minister who has picked up the recommendations from the Veterans' Entitlements Act Monitoring Committee, and has already, in this Bill, implemented nine of those recommendations. The veterans will judge people by their actions and not by their words, which is all we are hearing from the Opposition-words which, in reality, mean nothing for veterans. I support the Bill before the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Taylor Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, I commend the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee) for many of his bipartisan comments in what is clearly an area for bipartisan comment. However, before I say a few words about the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill, I should like to draw his attention to what the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) said in this place last evening. I refer him specifically to page 2532 of the Hansard record of 7 November in which the honourable member said:

SPEECH.PARA: We know from my list of 10 cutbacks that the right thing has not been done in recent years for the veteran and the war widow. This must be reversed. That is what the coalition policy is all about. We want a fair go for veterans. That is what the Government should be about. Instead, it is taking these tentative steps in that direction and not seeking comprehensively to reverse some of its cutbacks.

Also, I take up the point made by the honourable member for Dobell about the expenditure patterns. I point out to him that it is not a question of how much is spent but how well it is spent. Further, the policy document to which he referred is, of course, as he would recognise-and as has to be the case when an opposition exists-a broad blueprint for policy. Although I take the point that he is making, I do not think the point is well made.

Like my colleagues in this place last evening-the honourable member for Farrer and the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White)-I support the general thrust of the Bill but with some reservations and qualifications. I will come back in a moment to two in particular. Before I do that, I refer to three key provisions in the Bill to which the honourable member for Farrer referred last evening and which the honourable member for Dobell briefly referred to previously.

In the case of the extreme disablement adjustment, it provides to a severely disabled veteran, in addition to his or her disability pension, a further 50 per cent of the general rate if he or she, firstly, is beyond normal retiring age, is receiving or is eligible for a pension at 100 per cent of the general rate, is not receiving pension at the intermediate or special totally and permanently incapacitated (TPI) rate, and is severely disabled, as defined in the `Guide to the Assessment of Rates of Veterans' Pensions'. The Opposition commends that initiative but, as the honourable member for Farrer said last evening, clearly those criteria are highly constraining criteria and we draw the attention of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) to them. Clearly, they are in need of review.

The second point is on the TPI criteria where, currently, to qualify for a disability pension at the intermediate or special rate a veteran must be receiving or be eligible for a disability pension at 100 per cent of the general rate, be unable to work for more than a certain number of hours each week, and be unable to work because of war-caused disabilities alone and suffer an actual remuneration loss. The change initiated by the Bill is that the veteran need only be receiving or be eligible for a disability pension at 70 per cent of the general rate. That is a very commendable initiative on the part of the Government.

The third point is the adjustment of amputee rates of pension and certain allowances. The Bill adjusts amputee rates of pensions and certain allowances in respect of clothing, an attendant, recreation transport, and advance of travelling expenses. Adjustments in line with consumer price index (CPI) movements are allowed for but they are not the normal automatic half-yearly adjustments. Therefore, each year specific additional amendments are required to make annual upward adjustments in an isolated sense, and it seems to me, as it did to the honourable member for Farrer in this place last evening, that it would save money if this provision were amended so that CPI movements were allowed for on an automatic half-yearly basis. I commend those views to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs.

I now return to the two points that need emphasis. Firstly-and the honourable member for Dobell referred to this-repatriation is compensation and not welfare. Again, I refer to what the honourable member for Farrer said in this place last evening, as recorded at page 2533 of Hansard:

. . . repatriation is not welfare; disability pensions are not welfare; war widows' pensions are not welfare; service pensions are not welfare. They are compensation for what those people have suffered in the service of their nation.

I think the veteran community would object to any suggestion of that particular Department coming under the social security umbrella. If the Government is considering such a move, either in the short term or in the longer term, I suggest that it should think carefully, because the veteran community will not accept it; nor indeed will we, in government, accept anything less than a discrete Department of Veterans' Affairs.

The second point that needs emphasis concerns the series of cutbacks and complex changes impacting on veterans, war widows and ex-service personnel. I shall refer, once again, to the list to which the honourable member for Farrer referred last evening. Although I do not want to take up too much of the House's time, I shall quickly run through the changes and cutbacks in this area. In the May 1985 mini-Budget, the travel allowance was reduced by half, affecting country veterans in particular. The subsistence allowance was reduced substantially. The eligibility for some categories of service pensioners to utilise the repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme was terminated. Also, there were some limitations on the dental scheme.

In the Veterans' Entitlement Act 1986, the following changes were made: totally and permanently incapacitated pension criteria were tightened, with some veterans in the retirement phase of their lives no longer eligible for TPI benefits; provision was made for the termination of dependants' allowance by computation, albeit on a voluntary basis; and although repatriation cover was extended to those who had served on HMAS Sydney and other support ships between Australia and Vietnam, recognition by way of the appropriate awarding of medals remains undetermined.

Changes which arose from the 1986 Budget included the following: war widows and dependants, as well as service pensioners with their fringe benefits, no longer had access to the repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme; and war widows receiving an age pension had their social security component frozen at a maximum level of $60.05. An additional Budget decision to reduce the permanent maximum level below the $60.05 was dropped following a successful campaign by the Opposition. Provision was made for the Government to claim from private health insurance funds, where the veteran was insured, the cost of hospital and medical treatment which hitherto the Government would have paid for.

There was a six-week deferment, from early November of that year, of the CPI-related increases for veterans' pensions. Finally, under Budget-related legislation, the assets test resulted in over 13,000 veterans having their service pensions reduced or cancelled. More recently, there have been hardships imposed by the recent changes in the repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme as the honourable member for Farrer pointed out very clearly last evening, the Government imposed a statutory patient contribution, in excess of $5,000 per year, to operate from 1 January 1988 on veterans in nursing homes for war-related conditions-something, I might point out which was previously free of charge. There was also the 2 per cent cutback applied to the Defence Force retirement and death benefits pensioners in 1986, a decision that has never been rectified despite the Government's promise to do so.

On 20 October this year in this place, even the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren) was moved to make some salutary comments to his Government colleagues when he said, as recorded on pages 1989 and 1990 of Hansard:

However, my remarks today are strong criticism of those Ministers in the Hawke Cabinet whom I have often described as having cash registers for hearts and little understanding or compassion for war veterans or their widows.
He went on to say:

Since March 1983, the Hawke Government has eroded many of the conditions which had been gained, particularly under the Whitlam Government, and honoured by the Fraser Government. My argument is that the current Government should be more compassionate and more understanding in its policies.
Finally, he said:
It is about time that all the pennypinching, miserable and narrow minded people with cash register hearts had some compassion for some of the conditions of these ex-servicemen.

Surely, Mr Deputy Speaker, they are very telling criticisms from such a long-serving Minister in both the Whitlam and Hawke governments. They are criticisms from a man with a long period of service in the Parliament.

Mr Deputy Speaker, there is little doubt that ageing is a major problem in the community as we move towards the twenty-first century. It is a factor that is highlighted no more clearly than in the area of veterans, widows and their families. The average age of a veteran, depending on which statistics one studies, is between 69 and 71 years of age. The number of veterans over the age of 75 is increasing; and it will increase dramatically by the turn of the century. One in two or three of people in the community over 65 is a veteran.

At the present time, Repatriation Commission estimates indicate that there are 400,000 veterans or war widows eligible for treatment at departmental expense. Of that 400,000, 20 per cent are over the age of 75. By the year 2000, that number of 400,000 will drop to 280,000; but, of course, those over the age of 75 will increase from 20 per cent to 67 per cent. Therefore, as a community we have an ageing problem over the next 15 to 20 years, and the veterans community demonstrates clearly that problem.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I shall now refer to the report of a seminar held by the Returned Services League in Canberra on 3 September 1987. I shall refer to some comments that were made by General Morrison, who is the Services member of the Repatriation Commission. At that seminar he dealt with the way the Department should be dealing with the problem, as he saw it. He said that the way the Department dealt with the problem could provide a pilot for the Government when the community ageing problems increased dramatically during the next 15 to 20 years. He went on to talk about two issues. The first issue was the decentralisation of the Department's staff and resources to provide personalised help to veterans and war widows as they grow older, more feeble and less able to cope-with bureaucracy, of course, being one of the problems.

He said that the current system of appointing general practitioners as local medical officers to care for veterans and war widows was the linchpin of the repatriation treatment system, and should be continued. Of course, that would fit in very well with decentralisation. I agree entirely with those remarks, although I appreciate the resource implications of what General Morrison said.

The second matter to which he referred was the need to provide home help for those who were threatened with institutionalisation-in other words, that there was a need to make the homes of those who need help a care centre. He went on to say:
I am sure that the vast majority of our clients would rather remain independent and in their own homes than be placed in nursing homes or hostels.
He pointed out that there will be cases where there is a medical need for either nursing home or hostel care; and of course, the Department should pick up that arrangement.

He said that with ageing there could be a deterioration in mental capacity, in the ability to write or answer questions in writing and in the ability to read or to understand lengthy explanations, as well as a decrease, often to a marked degree, in the ability to get around. Older veterans' unwillingness or inability to travel to repatriation offices in major cities or their confusion over a multiplicity of health care services could lead them, as General Morrison said, `to give up and seek relief in institutional care'.

I welcome General Morrison's comments. As I understand it, he is also drafting a concept for the care of veterans beyond 2000 when the Federal Government's repatriation hospitals have been transferred to the State health systems. I hope that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, who is seated at the table, will be calling for that report in due course.

I conclude by drawing the attention of the House to what the honourable member for Farrer said in this place last evening, referring once again to the cutbacks, et cetera. He said that the Government should take account of recent criticisms of Government policies, priorities and administration in relation to the repatriation system and make the necessary adjustments as a matter of priority. I hope that the Minister will recognise that in his summing up of this debate and will take cognisance of what we on the Opposition benches are saying, that clearly we need to give a fair go to the veterans.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johns Mr G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak in favour of the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill. I am not happy to speak in favour of the amendment; in fact, I will oppose it. Although there is a fair amount of bipartisanship in this debate in as much as we are here really to congratulate the moves that will be ushered in by the new Bill, I think we should review where we have come from and consider some of our achievements in veterans' affairs. It is all very well for the Opposition to lay out a series of criticisms of the Government's position in veterans' affairs. It is all very well for the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) to criticise, as he did last night, the honourable member for Hawker (Mrs Harvey) for quoting broad expenditure figures in veterans' affairs. She mentioned that about $2.3 billion was spent on veterans' affairs in 1982-83 and that up to $4 1/2 billion will be spent this financial year. We acknowledge that most of that increase is due to inflation, the indexation of pensions and the greater number of persons requiring pensions.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me contrast that with the very small matters raised by the Opposition. I am not belittling them in the sense that they are not important matters, but they are pennies compared with the billions of dollars that this Government has been able to put into veterans' affairs. The main game in veterans' affairs has been about looking after the real value of veterans' pensions and benefits. We have done that exceedingly well. As veterans are at an age where they are beyond retirement they are in need of the best medical treatment, so we have concentrated a great amount of expenditure on looking after their health so that their incomes are secure and their health is as secure as medical knowledge can make it. That is where this Government has put its priorities.

We can debate a number of fringe issues, but I do not think the Opposition seems to realise the necessity actually to pay for the benefits of this last massive wave of World War II veterans. We are talking about tens of thousands of men and women who are entering retirement and old age who require the best in health and who require good pensions. We have been more than able to index the value of pensions and we can guarantee them the best in medical help. That is some achievement indeed in these economic times.

I acknowledge the point made by the honourable member for Farrer that repatriation is compensation, not welfare. We do not treat repatriation as welfare. We do not go around at the end of Budget sessions scraping up the last few dollars. The veteran pensioners get in there first-the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) makes sure of that. He makes sure that their pensions and the real value of those pensions are held. For instance, the move to integrate repatriation hospitals and the general State hospital system is because of, and in response to, the veteran community. It is not fair for the wife of an ill veteran in, say, Redcliffe in my electorate to have to travel all the way to Greenslopes, some 25 or 30 kilometres away, to visit her husband. A man may be in hospital for two, three or four months, given severe illnesses. It is not fair for a woman who is old to have to travel that distance. She may be unable to drive and, presumably, still has to run a household. We have solved the main game; we are looking after that major veteran community. The raising of minor matters by the Opposition would seem to belittle the Veterans' Affairs portfolio. I will not run through the Opposition's litany of criticisms as they simply do not help matters all that much.

Let me go to those significant matters that were picked up in the report of the Veterans' Entitlements Act Monitoring Committee. In fact, let me refer to the establishment of that Committee. Some two years ago we introduced the Veterans' Entitlements Act. That was the first uniform rewriting of the Repatriation Act since about 1920; it was the first time that it was brought together, renewed, reviewed and put to this Parliament. It needs to be said and repeated that at that time there were two huge problems in the repatriation area. The first related to the widows' pension and the second related to the definition of totally and permanently incapacitated (TPI).

Until about 1985 the Repatriation Commission had to prove beyond reasonable doubt in the case of a widow that a veteran's death was not related to his war service. In other words, there was a negative burden of proof. Thousands of cases were being pushed through involving veterans dying of unknown causes-for instance, medical science could not tell us how a veteran had died of a given cancer. It was impossible for any rational decisions to be made about the relationship between a veteran's death and his or her service. That was unfortunate because it led to a flood of claims whereby the Government and the Commission could not distinguish fantasy from fact. They could not distinguish between a person who had well and truly died because of a war caused injury and a person who had died for other reasons. I thought the whole process of awarding pensions because of war service brought the whole Act into disrepute, certainly into disrepair.

One of the major reforms of this Government was to allow the decision-makers to make rational, sensible decisions about the connections between war service and a veteran's incapacity or, indeed, death. It did not mean, as some veterans thought, that it was a device by which a government could deny veterans or widows a pension. In my experience, the decisions have been generous, honestly made and fair. They are made on a rational basis which does not require the veteran to prove that his injury arose directly as part of his war service. He simply requires some medical knowledge, usually, of the relationship between an injury or a particular habit that he may have picked up during the war, such as smoking, and a subsequent injury or condition, such as heart disease or emphysema or whatever. It is not a difficult point to prove-as long as there is some rational and often scientific basis to the connection, then the Commission or the Board has no problem whatsoever in awarding that pension. I believe that is an excellent reform of the last couple of years.

The other area where there was great confusion and where I believe the Opposition is still confused, because it keeps emphasising the difference between welfare and compensation, is in the TPI area. The TPI, the special rate of pension, was always known to be a compensation for a digger who, when he returned to civilian life, was unable to work because of his war experiences through injury or psychological damage or whatever. That worked well for 30 years post-World War II. When most of those veterans, as a group, came close to retirement, many were feeling the ill-effects of old age, and of a lifetime of work and some of the effects of their war service-a combination of all of those things.

After some time the Act was simply unable to distinguish the fact that the TPI was an award in lieu of the ability to work. In the last couple of years many disability pensioners were being awarded the TPI at an age beyond which they would never have worked. They had retired. This was unfortunate, because it lowered the real value of the notion of the TPI. It simply became something to be achieved by a veteran, rather than to be awarded to a veteran who could not work to support his family. Again in the previous Act there was a clarification which said that a worker who reached 65 could no longer be considered for TPI. This meant that there was a community-accepted age at which people retire and that if someone had well and truly retired the fact that he became ill after that time was not sufficient to allow him to be granted the TPI. We recognise that that left a number of disability pensioners who, having retired, became severely disabled. The Government has recognised that perhaps they should be due for some extra compensation; not a compensation for being unable to work, because that clearly would be wrong, but a compensation because of extreme disablement.

As part of this Bill, the Government is now seeking to compensate those beyond retirement age who are not on a TPI or special rate pension for severe disablement by granting them the general rate of pension plus 50 per cent, so that they will be well and truly cared for to the extent that money matters. Honourable members should never forget that we are talking about old people with great physical disability and, to the extent that money can really matter to them, we are prepared to come to the party. I suspect that what really matters to them is the best in medical care, the best in hospital services. That we can give, and that we have promised to continue to give.

If I can return to the TPI for a moment, an argument was put forward by the Returned Services League (RSL) and other groups that there should be a new test for the TPI. The current position is that war-caused disabilities alone should be the cause of a veteran's inability to work. The recommendation to the Government was that a different test be made asking whether the veteran would have been able to work but for war-caused disabilities. In other words, some of the veteran community were asking that there be an addition: let us look at the mixture of non-war-caused disability and war-caused disability leading to someone ceasing work. The problem there is the confusion about a person's working life, perhaps the 40 years spent at a job post-war. It confuses the notion of the TPI as a compensation for those who cannot work with the whole notion of workers' compensation which arises in the civilian area. The Government, quite rightly, has sought to separate those two notions. It is necessary to prove that it was the war-caused disability that stopped a man from working and, if that is so, that person deserves the TPI pension.

Finally, moving again to the extreme disablement adjustment, I was a little annoyed to read, in the latest RSL national newsletter, a letter from the Australian Capital Territory branch advocate of the RSL, Peter Kelly, who regards the new extreme disablement adjustment as `a con'. I presume he means a confidence trick. The heading to the article is `Veterans conned and cheated'. Quite frankly, that is unfair. The person obviously does not understand the notion of TPI as compensation for an inability to work and does not understand the notion of the extreme disablement adjustment. No-one is claiming that many veterans will receive the extreme disablement adjustment. In fact, the figures I have to hand are that something like 500 successful applications will be made in the year 1988-89 and perhaps around 1,000 successful applicants in 1989-90 at the cost of some $3m. The Government is acknowledging a group of people who really are severely disabled and who might well benefit from some extra income, but that has nothing whatsoever to do with the award of the TPI or with the whole notion of a TPI pension.

I conclude by congratulating the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) for his good work in having this Bill introduced. I know that as a government we will continue to receive inaccurate and unfounded criticisms. We will brush aside those that are indeed unfounded and, if any are founded, then I can assure the House that the Minister will be the first person to listen and to react.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome this opportunity to participate in this debate on the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill. During the nearly four years I have been in this Parliament, I have spoken on a number of occasions about matters that relate to veterans' affairs, because this issue is crucial to many thousands of people in my electorate of Gilmore. I think is is also crucial to a lot of thinking Australians who appreciate the efforts and sacrifice of a lot of people who have, in times gone by, given something to this country that a generation of Australians such as myself have never been called upon to give and hopefully will never be called on to give in the future. I thank the House for the opportunity to participate in the debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I commence on the areas that I want to speak on today, I would just like to take up a couple of the points that have been made by a number of speakers on the other side of the House in the course of this debate. Earlier this afternoon I heard one member of the Government suggesting that Opposition members were going around the countryside attending Returned Services Leagues clubs and sub-branch meetings and so forth, frightening members of the RSL community.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is true.

—It is not true. Although the honourable member tries to assert that, in his ignorance, it is not true. The majority of members on this side of the House, as I am sure is the case on the Government side, are keen to provide a service to their constituency, and in particular to the RSL constituency within their electorates. We are not in the business of frightening those people, and I might add that in most cases those people are beyond frightening. They have seen more things that are likely to frighten them than we could ever put before them. I make that point because it is most unfair of members of the Government to suggest, as the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland) suggested, that we go around the country frightening people. We do not. I, and I know my colleagues in the Liberal and National parties do also, go out there with the view of trying to deal with the genuine concerns that the veteran and ex-service community has in dealing with this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The previous speaker, the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Johns), went on about the fact that a number of people within the RSL organisation had misrepresented what the Government is trying to achieve through this legislation and through other Bills that have been put before this House over recent years. The honourable member for Petrie said that these allusions by members of the RSL are totally incorrect. But why do so many people in the veteran and ex-service community have the feeling that in recent years they have been given a poorer service from the Government, through the Department of Veterans' Affairs, than in the past? Certainly we all appreciate the administrative difficulties that the Department of Veterans' Affairs has. It is the subject of many complaints through my electorate office, some of which are valid and some of which are not, but I think the underlying principle behind these complaints that people in the ex-service community are now putting forward is that in the last 3 1/2 years there have been a number of setbacks from the veteran community.

I well remember that during my first year in this House, I think in May 1985, the Government made substantial changes to the Veterans' Entitlements Bill which resulted in this House being recalled to deal with matters that had been set upon us by the Senate. I recall also that the Government finally accepted 41 of the 42 amendments that the Opposition parties put forward, purely and simply because it recognised that its Bill of May 1985 had been deficient and had actually done a lot to frighten the veteran community. It had, in real terms, taken away a lot of the things that the veteran community had been given the impression was its right and its fair compensation. As a consequence, the Government had to accept 41 of the 42 amendments that we proposed. It recognised at the end of the day that we were right and it was wrong on those particular accounts. So there is a feeling dating back to May 1985 that veterans are being poorly treated by this Government.

I have a very large number of veterans living in my electorate, particularly in the coastal areas around the Shoalhaven district. Of course there are a number of active service personnel at HMAS Albatross and the Army parachute training school, and there are also those people working at HMAS Creswell but who live in my electorate-HMAS Creswell being in the seat of Fraser, in the Australian Capital Territory. So I have a large number of veterans; I am in good contact with them and they do genuinely feel hard done by. Their feelings were well represented by the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren) when he spoke in this House recently of his concerns about the Government's direction in dealing with the veteran community. The honourable member for Reid, who I think is the longest serving member of this Parliament, said:

However, my remarks today are strong criticism of those Ministers in the Hawke Cabinet whom I have often described as having cash registers for hearts and little understanding or compassion for war veterans or their widows.

That, coming from an honourable member on the Government side, a person with close contacts with the veteran and ex-service community, is substantial criticism of the way this Government has been treating our ex-service men and women over the last 3 1/2 years. The honourable member for Reid went on to say:
Since March 1983 the Hawke Government has eroded many of the conditions which had been gained, particularly under the Whitlam Government, and honoured by the Fraser Government.

It is that very sentiment that is felt very much amongst the ex-service community today. Is it any wonder, when we look at the deprivation that many of them suffered throughout the First World War, the Second World War and of course the Korean and Vietnam wars? Of course the honourable member for Reid was a victim of that suffering, having been a prisoner of war under the Japanese. He points out that the things that prisoners of war suffered were incomprehensible to the generation of Australians of which I am a member. As he points out, 550,000 Australians served in all theatres of the Second World War. Some 19,000 of them were killed in action. I think there were some 8,000 prisoners of war captured by the Germans and the Italians, all bar 300 of whom returned-the 300, of course, being killed or having died during their internment. There were 22,000 prisoners of war under the Japanese, only 14,000 of whom returned. The rest, of course, all died. Of those who returned, about half survive today. It is those who survive today, who have retired and are now finding that ailments that are a direct result of their imprisonment during the Second World War are causing them severe health and financial problems, and of course lifestyle problems, who feel an enhanced and acute need for good services from Government, and that is why the feeling exists in the veteran community today that the present Government is not living up to the expectation that was created by Ben Chifley, a former Labor Prime Minister, when he said:
On this Parliament rests the responsibility of seeing that the right thing shall be done.

It is the responsibility of this Parliament to ensure that the right thing is done. Since the Labor Government has been in power we have noticed a number of provisions being removed from the ex-service and veteran community. I will detail some of these. The travel allowance has been reduced by half, to a flat 11.6c per kilometre, with the reduction in government expenditure already totalling $3m. This affects country veterans in particular. Of course my electorate is a rural seat and the veterans who live there have on many occasions to travel to Sydney or Canberra for specialist treatment. They may have to attend the Concord General Repatriation Hospital, in Sydney. The halving of the travel allowance has had a severe financial impact of those people. It also means that they are not properly compensated for the cost of the accommodation or the meals they need in the course of their medical treatment in Sydney, and this has a big impact particularly on country veterans. The subsistence allowance for veterans, which I have just mentioned, has been reduced substantially resulting in their finding they are not able to be properly compensated. That has meant a saving to the Government of nearly $500,000. Of course this is why the honourable member for Reid refers to this Government as a collection of people with cash register hearts.

The eligibility of some categories of service pensioners to utilise the repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme has been terminated, and under the dental scheme four categories of treatment have been limited to a maximum benefit of $300 annually. Changes have arisen from the Veterans' Entitlements Act. Totally and permanently incapacitated pension criteria have been tightened up, and in fact veterans in the retirement phase of their lives are no longer eligible for the TPI pension. Once again that is referred to in the speech by the honourable member for Reid. Provision has been made for the termination of the dependants allowance by commutation, albeit on a voluntary basis, and there will be no further increase in the dependants allowance. Repatriation cover has been extended to those who served on HMAS Sydney and other support ships between Australia and Vietnam, but recognition by way of appropriate awarding of medals remains undetermined to this day.

Some changes have arisen from the 1986 Budget. War widows and their dependants, as well as service pensioners with their fringe benefits, will no longer have access to the repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme, but will still have access to the national health scheme at no cost. War widows who also receive an age pension will have their social security component frozen at a maximum level of $60.05. An additional Budget decision to apply a reducing permanent maximum level below $60.05 has now been dropped following a successful campaign. Provision has been made for the Government to claim from private health insurance funds with which veteran's may be insured the cost of hospital and medical treatment which hitherto the Government would have paid for. There will be a six-week deferment from early November of the consumer price index related increases for veterans' pensions. Under the Budget and related legislation the assets test continues to apply to veterans' service pensions. This has resulted in over 13,000 veterans having their service pensions reduced or cancelled. The coalition remains committed to abolishing the assets test in these areas.

Many people of our generation do not quite understand that veterans' entitlements are not social welfare payments; they are a right. They are a compensation that has been earned by the effort and suffering of those people who have served our nation in times of need in the past. I think it is very important that the Government understands some of the reasons why people in the community feel frightened. It is not because members of the Opposition are frightening them; it is because of the perceptions that this Government is transmitting to the community. I assure the Government that those perceptions are not well received.

The honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer), who led for the Opposition parties in the debate on this legislation, is worthy of compliment from members on this side of the House. I often hear Government members praise their Ministers for a job well done. I think it is time that we on this side of the House gave credit where credit is due. It is due to our shadow Minister for veterans' affairs, the honourable member for Farrer. He has worked tirelessly with the veteran community over the last few years.

TALK.START.PARA: —A good man.

SPEECH.PARA: I come back to some of the clear points with regard to this Bill. It is an attempt to provide a better service to veterans in our community. The Opposition is not opposed to the Bill. I raise some concerns which I have expressed to many veteran members in my constituency. I have raised them as a member of the Returned Services League (RSL). The reality is that our veterans are getting older. The numbers of veterans between now and the year 2000 will reduce. At a time when veterans want the best lobby and assistance to ensure they are politically represented in this place, they are getting the worst representation that they have ever had in the long history of the Returned Services League. We currently have a league which is concerned to become a political lobby group, not so much concerned with veterans' benefits and welfare but with all sorts of things. Be it trade unions, conservation, immigration, you name it, the RSL is into it.

I have expressed to veterans in my RSL group that the age of members in this Parliament, logically, is reducing. There will in the future be fewer members of the Australian Parliament who have any memories of events which occurred between 1939 and 1945. Vietnam is to many Australians history, not something that happened during their lifetime or in their memories. As members of this House come from a younger generation and those of us who have memories of those events get older and die, I wonder who will be around to ensure that those veterans are still protected politically and that those veterans get the compensation they deserve. When the RSL is increasingly becoming a joke in the community and is seen by so many younger members of our community as irrelevant to contemporary conditions, I wonder just what sort of a deal veterans will get as these younger members of the Australian population who hold that view about the RSL move into this place as politicians.

The RSL to me and to many Australians has a fundamental role to play in ensuring that veterans are well represented. It is the most powerful lobby group that veterans have. The day that the veterans move away from that organisation will be a sad day for them. The fact that the RSL is now wanting to enlarge its membership to include people irrespective of whether they have served in the Services and is totally opening its membership indicates to me that the current leadership of the RSL is more concerned about the future of the RSL as an organisation than as a veterans organisation.

The day the RSL becomes a body in which veterans have the minority membership and non-veterans the majority membership will be the day that the RSL, in my view, loses much of its political clout. That day will be the day that veterans will no longer have an organisation which truly represents them. That concern is one that I have expressed to the servicemen in my electorate. I am pleased to say that they understand that concern. They understand it because they know that the moment their organisation is no longer veteran controlled and is controlled by some of the right wing lunatics we see in this country and who now so often speak for the RSL is the day they will not be represented at all.

It is about time that more politicians stood up in this place and expressed concern about that. They should be concerned not so much about the views held by some of these people-they are nonsense views in any event and do not have any credibility in the community-but rather about the effect on the RSL itself and on veterans themselves. I say without question to this House that I know that in my electorate the vast majority of RSL members are strong Australian Labor Party supporters. We should never forget that the returned servicemen are primarily the workers who came from blue overall conditions, fought, came back and are still strong Labor people. The Bill, of course, is well worth while. I do not know why we are debating it. It is worth while noting the increase in the August Budget and the effect that that will have on the veteran community. It is interesting to note that income support has increased by 2.5 per cent. It is up now to $3.252m. That I find very valuable. The amount for health is up. It is noticeable that housing assistance has increased by 55.7 per cent, which is quite a massive increase.

Does the Opposition believe that the process of consultation whereby the veteran community is asked to come to the consulting table and put recommendations to the Government is not the way to go about providing proper benefits for veterans? I think it is time the Opposition stood up in this House and told us how it would go about it. I ask the shadow Minister for veterans' affairs, the honourable member for Farrer, who is at the table, when he is going to produce to this House costings of the proposals contained in the Opposition policy statement. Are they approved by the shadow Minister for finance, the honourable member for Wentworth? What will be the effect of the tax proposals when eventually the Opposition comes up with a tax proposal? Will there be moneys in the Opposition's proposal to pay for the increased costs? How can the Opposition possibly say to this House, until it has a tax policy, that it has money to do it? I await with some anxiety for all of those matters. I will be pleased when this House can in fact debate them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pratt Mr M.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset may I support a couple of points made by the previous speaker, the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland). Comprehensive costings and proposals have been put forward by the Opposition, as the shadow Minister for veterans' affairs, the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer), has indicated. We also reaffirm strongly that there will be no cutbacks on veterans under a coalition government.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a number of positive aspects to this legislation for which the Government should be rightly commended. I plan to deal with those first. It will take only a minute. Firstly, and possibly most importantly, the extreme disability adjustment to be enacted by this Bill is a welcome move. The EDA, to reduce it to its diminutive, provides to a severely disabled veteran an addition to his or her disability pension. This means that if the veteran concerned meets a number of criteria he or she will receive a further 50 per cent of the general rate-an extra $42.15 a week.

The criteria are as follows: the veteran must be beyond the normal retirement age, must be receiving or be eligible for a pension at 100 per cent of the general rate, must not be receiving pension at the intermediate or totally and permanently incapacitated (TPI) rate and must be severely disabled, as defined in the guide to the assessment of rates of veterans' pensions. Apart from the fact that the criteria are somewhat too stringent-to the point where only absolute cot cases will qualify-the extra benefit enacted by the EDA provision is welcomed by the Opposition.

I have some more praise for the Government in this very sensitive area of veterans' affairs. Currently, to qualify for a disability pension at the intermediate or special rate, a veteran must be receiving or be eligible to receive a disability pension at 100 per cent of the general rate, be unable to work for more than a certain number of hours each week and be unable to work because of war-caused disabilities alone, and suffer an actual remuneration loss. The change initiated by this legislation is that the veteran need only be receiving or be eligible to receive a disability pension at 70 per cent of the general rate. This freeing up of eligibility requirements is also welcomed by the Opposition.

I move on to the third bouquet for the Government, regarding the application date. At present, to qualify for a disability pension at the intermediate or TPI rate, a veteran must meet all the eligibility criteria on the day he or she lodges his or her claim or application. The change initiated by this legislation will mean that a veteran will qualify for a disability pension if he or she meets all the eligibility criteria at any one date between the date of lodgment of claim and the date the decision is made. This is a further step forward and again is welcomed by the Opposition.

It is interesting to note that the speaker who led for the Government on this Bill last night, the honourable member for Hawker (Mrs Harvey), mentioned only these three points, the three aspects of the legislation on which I have congratulated the Government. That speaker missed another positive aspect of the Bill, that which frees up the remarriage provisions. The current position is confirmed in this legislation, that is, where a dependant of a deceased veteran had remarried prior to 28 May 1984, no war widow's pension is payable. But there is good news for some. Those who remarried after that date are eligible to retain the war widow's pension. However, it should be pointed out that this Government, due to its clumsy approach, has created two categories of remarried war widows-the lucky ones who remarried after the magic date and the unlucky ones who remarried before it. This gives us a clue as to why the Government's first speaker neglected to mention this aspect of the Bill. It is typical of the Hawke Labor Government's cynical and contemptuous attitude to veterans, pensioners and retirees in our community.

The changes and cutbacks in veterans' affairs during the term of the Hawke Labor Government are a disgrace. It is a nonsense to suggest, as did the Government speaker last night, that Labor has doubled the veterans' affairs budget. The bare truth is that Veterans' Affairs has spent twice as much because it is being used twice as much as veterans get older and their health begins to fail. The Department's own figures show the average age of veterans to be 71. This is a real world example, a factual indicator of one of the most insidious aspects of the sneaking, creeping socialism that is an integral part of this Labor Government.

Part of Labor's agenda is to hand the repatriation general hospital system over to the States by 1995, or earlier if some States have their way. With the average age of veterans being 71, the next seven years is precisely the time that the veterans will need the repatriation system most. More than 200 veterans, pensioners and their spouses attended a public meeting I convened in my electorate less than a fortnight ago, using the excellent facilities that the Gilles Plains-Hampstead Returned Services League branch maintains. They were unanimous in their resolve to save the repatriation system and maintain a separate department of Veterans' Affairs.

Discussion in the Senate Estimates Committee D hearings showed that a structural change is well under way within the Department to facilitate all veterans' matters becoming the concern of State authorities. At my `Save the Repat' meeting, a number of veterans complained about being turned away from the Daw Park repatriation hospital in time of emergency. One man, a TPI pensioner, who spoke from the floor at that meeting, said that he had been refused three out of four times-on two occasions as he lay in the back of an ambulance. There was no room at the inn. Yet, when specifically questioned at Estimates Committee D hearings, an officer of the Department denied that this was the case. I quote from the Hansard transcript of Estimates Committee D for 10 October 1988. The following question was asked:
Are veterans being turned away from any of the RGHs for either elective surgery, medical treatment or any other reason?
The answer was:

In terms of elective surgery, we believe that at Heidelberg there may be two or three per week being turned away, and at Greenslopes about eight per week. We believe there are none at all in Daw Park nor Hollywood.
With reference to medical treatment or other purposes, the same officer said:
Heidelberg estimates that 40 a week are turned away . . . For Daw Park and Hollywood it is again nil.

Clearly, the Department and the veterans are at odds, and the veterans are wild about it. To paraphrase Prime Minister Ben Chifley, clearly this Parliament has a responsibility to these people. Obviously, that responsibility is not served by handing over the repatriation system to the States, which are already using its facilities to a point where veterans are being turned away. That responsibility is clearly not served by the new scheme of the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) to catch age pensioners with the new rules concerning the income test, which make it impossible for the elderly, veterans included, to protect their life savings from the ravages of inflation.

I encourage the Hawke Labor Government to consider more of the positive changes engendered in some aspects of this legislation, but I condemn it for its penny-pinching, miserable and narrow-minded cash register approach. As our second reading amendment states, whilst we support the general thrust of the Bill, we are of the view that repatriation is compensation, and not welfare, in acknowledgment of the service of our veterans, war widows, ex-service personnel and serving personnel.

There has been a series of cutbacks and complex changes impacting on veterans, war widows and ex-service personnel representing, as I said, a penny-pinching, miserable and narrow-minded cash register approach that is typified by a $300 limit on certain categories of dental treatment within the one year, the halving of the country travel allowance for veterans referred to specialists and repatriation general hospitals, the hardship imposed by the recent changes in the repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme, the imposition of a statutory patient contribution in excess of $5,000 a year from 1 January last on veterans in nursing homes for war-related conditions, the massive delays in the determining system, thus denying justice where veterans die before a decision is made, and the 2 per cent cutback which was applied to Defence Force retirement and death benefits veteran pensioners in 1986 and which has never been rectified, despite promises by the Government to do so.

I conclude my contribution in supporting the attitude of members on this side of the House to veterans' affairs by reminding the House of the statement made by the shadow Minister for veterans' affairs. His catchphrase, which all members of the coalition support, is `a fair go for veterans'. I repeat: repatriation is compensation, not welfare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the amendment moved by the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) and seconded by the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White), I start by noting that there is probably no better example to be found of the difference between the rhetoric of the Government and what it actually does than in an examination of the conduct of veterans' and war widows' affairs under the present regime. The Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill which is before the House is one of the less controversial Bills. And so it should be, because one of its main provisions is a direct pinch from the Opposition's policy. There have been many removals of and cutbacks in the entitlements of veterans and war widows during the successive terms of this Hawke-Keating regime unmatched by any previous government. The Treasurer (Mr Keating), the would-be Prime Minister, deserves special recognition for that state of affairs. It is under his stewardship that retirees generally, and veterans and their dependants in particular, have experienced the greatest decline in living standards since the Great Depression. This has taken place over a period just in excess of 5 1/2 years. We on the Opposition side and those affected are entitled to ask: why is there this seemingly indecent concentration on veterans, war widows and their dependants? Why has spending for these purposes been subjected to the machete that the Treasurer so cheerfully wields? Why do we have all those ridiculous programs that finance minority groups to parade their prejudices around the country at taxpayers' expense? Why not slash funds for artists in residence employed by unions, for spurious make-work programs, or for a whole catalogue of wanton waste identified by the Opposition's Waste Watch Committee? Those are legitimate questions for which there are no legitimate answers. The reason, of course, is that the reductions in and the removals of entitlements are merely cost-cutting measures.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's priorities are made abundantly clear in its treatment of veterans, war widows and their dependants. It is for the purpose of highlighting those priorities that the Opposition has moved its second reading amendment in terms expressed by my colleague the honourable member for Farrer. He has tabulated the extent and dimensions of measures which have figured so prominently in the dramatic drop in living standards to which I have referred. Some have had a more dramatic effect than others, but it is the cumulative effects over the terms of the present Government that have caused the damage that has been done. It is the relentless assault on veterans and war widows benefits in successive measures that has set the scene for the greatest drop in living standards since the Great Depression. I take just one example which is typical of many of a particular type brought to my attention by constituents. The relevant parts of my constituent's letter are succinct and straightforward enough to quote verbatim and in full and I do so:

Thank you for your letter of June 88, and for your offer of help to people in your electoral area. This is a matter of taxation that should be corrected. Aged pensioners with a small other income are being assessed income tax on their small total income. I have an income of $5674 for 1987-88, and a part pension of $4282 for 1987-88. The pension is reduced on account of the income and I do not receive any pensioner's concessions. I am not complaining about this, but I am complaining of being assessed $1187 tax on a total income of $10,047 for the year 1987-88.

There we have it. Not only have benefits been slashed but also income tax has become a factor not previously applicable to pensioners with the purchasing power of the pensioner whose letter I just quoted. As I explained to that gentleman, the Government's lack of consideration for retirees seems to have more to do with collecting information which must be disclosed in tax returns lodged by pensioners, thus enabling cross checking by the Department of Social Security, than with any sound principle of government. It is indefensible that, although this man and veterans and other pensioners like him may earn certain income which will not affect entitlements to partial pensions and associated benefits, they are, nevertheless, obliged to file a tax return and to pay income tax. The fact that the total income tax payable by such individuals is negligible in terms of revenue for the Government is not enough to persuade it that those with the obligation should not have to bear either the inconvenience or the cost.

Of course, it is as sure as night follows day that the Treasurer will do next year what he should have done last year. With an eye to the next election he will want to be seen to be pulling another rabbit out from that copious space under his hat, the undertaker's hat that the cartoonists depict as part of his uniform. One does not have to be a student of magic or of those other than the Treasurer who practise the science of illusion to know what is to happen next. Around May next year when the Treasurer announces his illusory tax cuts we will be told that pensioners of all kinds, including veterans and war widows, will no longer be up for income tax if they are in circumstances similar to those set out in the letter from which I have already quoted. A further cynical deceit will be practised in the grand tradition of similar cynicism which has become a hallmark of this Government.

It can be confidently anticipated that from July next year the Government, as part of its grand plans for deception in the run-up to the next election, will increase the tax-free threshold so that veteran beneficiaries and other pensioners will not have to pay income tax as they do at present. The tricky part in selling the deceit will be to convince everyone to overlook or forget the fact that the inequity to be remedied was created by and was an inevitable consequence of the problems created without help by the selfsame Government which will claim credit for at last finding a remedy. It is the old straw man trick: build one up, then take the credit for knocking it down, and expect the electorate to say in the ballot box, `Thank you very much, your eminences, for saving us from an even worse standard of living'. That is entirely consistent with the arrogant thinking and demeanour of the Treasurer. In the meantime, pensioners like my constituent will have paid income taxes for the years 1987-88 and 1988-89 to an extent never before experienced under any previous Commonwealth government.

There can be no group of people more disadvantaged over the terms of successive Keating-Hawke governments than retirees and those approaching retirement. Veterans, war widows and their dependants have probably suffered more than most. There has been a succession of legislated changes including, but not limited to, assets and means testing, health care, taxes on superannuation funds, and removal of incentives for individuals to provide for their retirement without imposing unduly on taxpayers. Each change has dealt a blow to the living standards of retirees on fixed or investment incomes, including those who supplement benefits by obtaining rewards for their own personal exertion. Because there have been so many changes over the period, great uncertainty has been created and, as is well known, I am sure, uncertainty is probably the greatest cause of worry to pensioners, particularly amongst those who are no longer young.

A good example affecting veterans and war widows was the mini-Budget announcement last May, which foreshadowed the Government's intention to count, for pension purposes, ongoing annual income earned on, but not distributed to investors in, certain investments such as insurance bonds. The subsequent abandonment of that part of the measure which would have required such income over the three previous years to comprise the basis of initial means testing, and taking that form, confers no credit on this Government either. That abandonment was not because of any matter of great principle or some pang of conscience suddenly occurring to the Government; it was because of a State election in the offing in Victoria, and the political heat was too great.

Another constituent has written to me to give clear examples of how, earlier, assaults by this Government on the incomes of retirees have materialised. Veterans and pensioners generally will identify if not with the detail then certainly with the spirit of the real and perceived wrongs perpetrated by this Government on retirees in all categories. I quote from the letter from that constituent and I ask the question: Is it just another unintended consequence of careless legislation? This is what my constituent had to say:
