That is typical of the sentiments constantly relayed to my colleagues and me. The full gambit of our concerns and criticisms has been more than adequately dealt with by previous Opposition speakers including the honourable members for Farrer, McPherson, Groom (Mr Taylor) and Adelaide (Mr Pratt).

In thereby having the opportunity and the comparative luxury to dwell on some of the detail of our concerns and criticisms, I can do no better than to instance the objections of none other than the President of the Legacy Club of Perth. Mr J. C. Lillie had some particularly telling observations to make about the announced intention to place some 53 prescription drugs in common use on what was loosely described, in the announcement, as a `Special Authority List'.

The President of Perth Legacy is not a person whose opinions and observations can be taken lightly. His interest is bred of concern and of first-hand experience. As the elected leader of an organisation which currently offers support to some 7,000 dependants of those who have served their country in war and who have died, the President of Perth Legacy is, one might say, uniquely placed. The Government would do well to listen to him. He claims, as the Opposition parties have said on countless occasions, that his members, `are concerned at the continuing erosion of benefits to war widows in the area of pharmaceutical benefits'. One should remember that that concern was expressed as a result of field evidence and it was not the outcome of bureaucratic procrastination based on who knows what criteria.

The worry engendered by uncertainty which followed the announcement to remove 53 drugs from the pharmaceutical benefits list was unnecessary in the event. The President of Perth Legacy had this to say about it:
We strongly resent the recent decision of the Commonwealth Government to place 53 prescription drugs on a `Special Authority List' and believe that:
1. Decisions as to the best drug for a patient should be made on medical justification not price;
2. The best person to decide about the patient's medication is the patient's doctor-not a public servant;
3. The new procedure may cause delays in patients receiving urgently needed medication;
4. Patients with acute illnesses may be denied access to the most appropriate medication.
He went on to conclude:
The recent legislation-
meaning the announcement, I presume-

means that a Public Servant and not the patient's Doctor now has the final decision as to whether a particular patient will be supplied with the drug which his Doctor considers to be the best appropriate medication.

The fact that the Government, in the face of resentment like that, now intends, I think, to recant and perhaps relist some 30 or more of those prescription drugs into the pharmaceutical benefits list shows how thoughtless and inconsiderate was the original decision. On its own this example might have been dismissed as a mere aberration but it cannot be dismissed so lightly. It is but one of a whole raft of successive measures over the past 5 1/2 years which have disadvantaged veterans, war widows and their dependants.

Just as important, and perhaps even more so is the worry inflicted on those who are not so young any more. It is part of the mean, penny-pinching attitude relentlessly adopted by the Government, and referred to in this House by the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren) a couple of weeks ago. It is not just the provision of relevant legislation which qualifies and quantifies benefits; there are also tax measures of the type I have already mentioned.

The assault on the living standards of veterans, war widows and their dependants continues on all sides and unabated. It is to be deplored. The Government deserves the condemnation foisted upon it from time to time in this connection. It is in the light of this situation that the second reading motion amendment has been moved and refers to, among many other criticisms and concerns of the opposition, a series of cutbacks and complex changes impacting on veterans, war widows and ex-service personnel.

As the amendment states, the Government should take account of recent criticisms of government policies, priorities and administration in relation to the repatriation system, and make the necessary adjustments as a matter of priority. Regrettably, we see no sign of that, but we look forward to the day when reality sets in.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Farrer has moved an amendment containing matters far removed from the contents of this Bill. I will deal with the matters mentioned in the amendment later, but before that I will bring the debate back to the Bill before the House and certain other extraneous matters canvassed by the shadow Minister. During consultations held before the debate, the honourable member for Farrer and the National Secretary of the Returned Services League (RSL) expressed concern over certain aspects of the Bill and asked that I give assurances as to the operation of clause 10 and clause 21 (b) of the Bill.

Clause 10 sets out in some detail the manner in which a decision maker deals with a claim for disability pension or an application for an increase in the rate of disability pension. Clause 10 requires the Repatriation Commission, the Veterans' Review Board (VRB) or the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) to assess the rates of pension payable to a veteran from the application day up to and including the date of their decision.

The effect of this amendment in relation to intermediate or special rate pension is to ensure that a pension is payable from the first day in the assessment period on which all the relevant criteria are met. That rate of pension would continue for life under the provisions of section 24a of the Veterans' Entitlements Act.

In relation to the general rate pension, the amendment requires that if the rate to which a veteran is entitled varies because of changes in the degree of incapacity, the rate of pension payable during the assessment period can vary accordingly. For example, where the veteran's incapacity on the day of application is assessed at 50 per cent of the general rate and deteriorates prior to determination, a higher rate of, say, 80 per cent can be paid from a day prior to the determination day. In such an example the veteran would receive 50 per cent from the application day and then 80 per cent from the day of the deterioration to the day of determination and thereafter.

Because of his concern over the words `from time to time', the honourable member for Farrer has suggested that the clause be amended. I do not agree an amendment is necessary. The proposed amendment in the Bill does what the Government intends-that is, it enables payment of the pension at the appropriate rate from the first day during the assessment period the veteran becomes eligible for that rate. The honourable member has sought an assurance that no veteran would be denied benefits because of the change of terminology made by clause 21 (b). Clause 21 (b) will substitute the term `prisoner of war' in paragraph 85 (4) (b) of the Veterans' Entitlements Act for `detained by the enemy'. This is purely a presentational change requested by the Ex-Prisoners of War Association to revert to the words previously used in the Repatriation Act. I am happy to assure the honourable member and the veteran community that the amendment does not affect eligibility nor is it intended to result in any change to existing or future entitlements.

The honourable member has expressed some concern that the reference in paragraphs 23 and 24 (1) (a) to new section 21a is anomalous in that the latter provision does not come into effect until royal assent whereas the former is specified to have come into effect on 22 May 1986. The technical effect of this would appear to be that paragraphs 23 and 24 (1) (a) would refer to a provision which did not exist prior to this Bill receiving royal assent. The honourable member has sought an assurance that this amendment will not adversely affect any existing or future claims or applications which are determined on or after royal assent. Such claims or applications, where they involve an assessment of the degree of incapacity of a veteran from his or her war-caused conditions, will be required to be determined in accordance with new section 21a. I am happy to give this assurance.

Another concern is the eligibility criteria for the proposed extreme disablement adjustment (EDA). This concern was also raised by the RSL during consultation. The honourable member perhaps overlooks the fact that the Government adopted the specific recommendation of the Veterans' Entitlements Act Monitoring Committee to set the criteria in the Bill. The target population of the EDA identified by the Monitoring Committee is a small group of frail and aged veterans seen to warrant extra compensation. The EDA is an extension of the general rate and is not based on a work related test as is the special rate. It follows that a veteran needs to have reached a pension rate of 100 per cent before proceeding to the new higher rate of, effectively, 150 per cent. Experience with the application of the criteria will indicate whether the needs of the target group has been satisfied.

The matter of whether the Veterans' Entitlements Act should provide for coverage of United Nations peacekeeping forces in Iran and Iraq and naval clearance divers has also been raised in debate by the honourable member. The Australian military contingent in Iran and Iraq, and the naval clearance divers in the Persian Gulf, have the cover available to all serving members of the Defence Force under Part 4 of the Veterans' Entitlement Act. In addition, they have the cover provided by the Commonwealth Government employees compensation scheme. It is not necessary to include any legislative amendment in respect of the peacekeeping forces or naval divers to provide them with adequate cover. However, appropriate action to gazette the military contingent as a peacekeeping force to give it the benefit of the more beneficial standard of proof is in hand. I will take up with the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) the question of determining the service of the naval divers to be `hazardous service' to put these personnel on the same footing.

In respect of minor benefits and allowances, these are increased annually, based on the consumer price index movements in the previous July to June financial year. This has occurred since the 1980-81 Budget. I will seek to index automatically minor benefits and allowances in the next Budget.

I now turn to the Opposition's proposed amendment. This is an obvious device to lead debate away from the Government initiatives in the Bill and yet again to generate unnecessary anxiety within Australia's ageing veteran community. Let me put some of these matters right, Mr Deputy Speaker. The honourable member has requested that the Government treat repatriation as compensation. I am amazed that the honourable member would make such a request. Surely he is aware that pensions payable for war caused or defence caused incapacity or death are already treated as such and are tax and income test free.

This Government is acutely aware that it must recognise the changing needs of the veteran community and provide adequate compensation. This awareness is reflected in the Bill which is presently before the House. For example, the introduction of the extreme disablement adjustment clearly demonstrates the Government's awareness and willingness to respond to the identified needs of the veteran community.

The honourable member for Farrer referred to the $300 limit on certain categories of dental treatment. Criticism such as this overstates the effect of the $300 limit, which applies only to the more expensive categories of treatment, such as bridge work and gold inlays. The most important basic dental care and ordinary acrylic dentures are not subject to any limit. Dental care required as treatment for war caused injury or disease, or as a result of cancer, is also exempt from the limit. The $300 limit will be addressed as part of the current review of the local dental officer scheme being undertaken by my Department in consultation with the Australian Dental Association.

The travel allowance for veterans who use their own vehicles to travel for treatment was aligned in 1985 with allowances paid by other Commonwealth agencies for similar travel. The allowance paid by DVA is currently set at 12.28c per kilometre and covers normal running costs such as petrol, tyres and repair components associated with attending medical appointments. The subsistence allowance for meals and accommodation covers the reasonable expenses incurred in undergoing treatment.

The changes to the repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme (RPBS) do not impose hardships on veterans. They more closely align the drugs available to the veteran community with those available to the non-veteran community under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. However, while we ask local medical officers normally to prescribe the drugs available under the scheme to the rest of the community, other medic- ation may also be provided where clinically justified through the prior approval prescribing arrangements of the RPBS.

As the honourable member for Farrer has indicated, the Government decided that, from 1 January 1988, all entitled persons in an institution for nursing home care will be required to pay the statutory patient contribution. About 6,000 entitled persons receive nursing home care annually, at the expense of the Department. About 880 have been affected by this decision. The patient contribution of around $117 a week represents a contribution towards the cost of board and lodgings for which patients would be responsible at home or in hostels. Most DVA beneficiaries in nursing homes have always met the patient contribution. However, prior to 1 January 1988, the Repatriation Commission accepted financial responsibility for the patient contribution of those beneficiaries admitted to nursing homes specifically as a result of war caused disabilities. The Repatriation Commission will continue to meet the major portion of the cost of nursing home care up to the maximum Commission benefit. This currently ranges from about $400 per week to around $600 per week, depending on the State in which the veteran resides. Financial responsibility will also be accepted for all other medical costs additional to normal nursing home care.

It must also be remembered that all age pensioners in the general community have to meet the patient contribution and many veterans would have more income than their civilian counterparts. Many receive disability pensions in addition to service pensions. I thank the honourable member for Farrer for raising the question of delays in the determining system. At the primary level, there has been a marked reduction in delays. Between June 1985 and June 1988, the average time taken dropped from 347 to 171 days for claims for the acceptance of disabilities and from 280 to 142 days for applications for increases. The Government acknowledges that there is still room for improvement at the primary level in this regard. The Government has accepted all four recommendations made by the Veterans' Entitlements Act Monitoring Committee which were aimed at reducing delays. A strategy for implementation is being developed.

In relation to the recommendations of the Veterans' Entitlement Act Monitoring Committee, which is what we are really debating tonight, I have given the honourable member for Farrer full and detailed answers to the questions he asked. I remind the House that the honourable member for Farrer stated in his policy speech that the Opposition will do all sorts of wonderful things that responsible governments can do when economic resources permit. Of the 58 recommendations of the Veterans' Entitlements Act Monitoring Committee, a body which the honourable member for Farrer stated he supported, the Government accepted 28. We accepted a further four in a modified form and another 20 are receiving further consideration.

The fact is that last year's surplus of about $2 billion and the estimated surplus of $5.5 billion for this year have been overwhelmingly achieved by increases in taxation. TALK.START.PARA: —It is a disgrace.

SPEECH.PARA: Is it not interesting how the debate on most Bills in this Parliament turns to the question of tax? It is ridiculous for the Treasurer to masquerade outside Australia as paying off some of the Government's net foreign debt under the guise of restoring our `national sovereignty'. For instance, in what was unquestionably a rambling answer to a question without notice that I asked the Treasurer on 20 October, he said:
As the Government diminishes its own debt abroad, there is therefore a gain on the net income transfer and that gain is reflected in yesterday's current account figures . . .

Simply put, that answer was wrong. The Treasurer either does not know what he is talking about or he is being downright misleading concerning Australia's foreign debt. The current account deficit for September brings the total deficit for the first quarter of 1988-89 to $3.8 billion compared to $3.4 billion in the same quarter last year. Official capital outflow was over $1 billion, but private capital inflow of nearly $5 billion in that month was required to finance the current account deficit plus the Treasurer's debt repayments. Simply put, our net capital inflow has actually increased; hence, as a nation, our obligation to foreigners has increased.

All that the Treasurer has achieved, if anything, is to change the mix of the net capital inflow from the public sector to the private sector. The Government simply cannot escape from the fact that since it came to office in 1983 Australia's net foreign debt has nearly quadrupled and now stands at $89 billion. The Treasurer has masqueraded around the world as having allegedly repaid debt, yet the debt has increased at home while he was away. The reason for it is absolutely basic: it is economic mismanagement.

In its first two Budgets the Keating-Hawke Government's fiscal deficits swallowed our national savings to the tune of about $15 billion. As a result they forced Australia to borrow increasingly overseas. Despite the recent surplus we are still suffering from this fiscal vandalism. Our net foreign debt stubbornly keeps rising. The Government is continually regaling us with claims that our external position is improving. The actual figures are less inspiring.

That the pace of adjustment of our huge foreign debt is too slow is shown by three simple facts: first, the fact that net exports are expected to make a negative contribution to gross domestic product yet again in 1988-89; secondly, the fact that imports of capital goods as a share of total imports fell again in 1987-88; and, thirdly, the fact that investment in mining and manufacturing is expected to show little, if any, real growth in 1988-89. Senator Walsh, as is usual after a Budget is brought down, told us the truth. As he said on the Face to Face program a few weekends ago:
Any country which has a foreign debt the size that Australia has and a continuing current account deficit is very vulnerable to international pressure.

That is why Moody's Investor Services Inc. continues to refuse to restore Australia's AAA international credit rating. The Budget strategy is unquestionably precariously based on continued strong commodity prices. The riskiness of the Budget is highlighted by International Monetary Fund forecasts that 1989 will see an easing of world commodity prices due to slower world economic growth. The recent decline of the State Bank of Victoria's commodity price index, which has fallen by 12 per cent in US dollar terms since 10 June, certainly does not augur well.

The fragility of our balance of payments position certainly has implications for next year's tax cuts. Does the House remember what was said about the tax cut? It was said that it would be the biggest tax cut in the history of this country. Those were the words of one of Labor's de facto Cabinet members, Mr Kelty of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. On 25 August this year, in response to a question by me in this House on the funding of next year's tax cut, the Treasurer said that the tax cut would be funded from the Budget surplus. Terrific! He will walk away from reducing public demand-if he is so worried about overheating of the private sector, by cutting Government expenditure to pay for the tax cuts. As well as quadrupling the debt in a period in which we have high inflation rates, high interest rates and high rates of taxation, he will give the tax cut based on the surplus. In reality, the Treasurer is intent on providing next July's tax cuts without cutting government expenditure. In the absence of reductions in government spending the Government cannot possibly provide the promised and much needed tax cuts, next July without blowing out the balance of payments even further.

The Opposition has consistently argued for tax cuts funded by reductions in government spending. Reductions in outlays release labour and capital to the private sector, including export and import competing industries. Tax cuts increase the incentives to both work and invest. Moreover, cuts in government spending will curb growth in public sector demand, as I said, permitting a rise in private sector demand without risking a further blowout in imports. Following the validity of that sort of argument, the Opposition's fiscal policy, in conjunction with our industrial relations policy, will improve Australia's competitiveness and productivity.

Finally, I want to raise another aspect dealing with the Bill we are debating tonight. The two recent repayments of yen and Swiss franc debt revealed a very large exchange rate loss over the duration of the loans. Some management! Because the Commonwealth had not effectively hedged these loans, it realised a foreign exchange loss of about $144m on the Swiss franc debt and a loss of $212m on the Japanese loan. That is over $350m in losses in just these two loans. Failure to adequately protect itself against foreign currency movements is unquestionably a condemnation of the Government's past debt management. The cost of hundreds of millions of dollars should not have to be borne by the taxpayer.

The amendments we will introduce to this Bill should go part of the way to addressing these problems. But the reality is that the Government has failed in its management of our debt. Quite apart from increasing it, the Government has been unable to manage it effectively. Hopefully these amendments will assist the Government in doing that. But the root cause is the weakness of the Australian dollar against such currencies as the Swiss franc and the Japanese yen. That weakness itself stems from a weak and vulnerable economy buffeted by the cruel winds of the international marketplace. The Government has to hasten the pace of economic adjustment and make the Australian economy less vulnerable.

The changes in this Bill address some of the symptoms of the problem facing Australia. More emphasis, however, must be given to the necessary fiscal task and the necessary micro-economic reform. The Opposition's proposal to cut back taxes based on cuts in government expenditure and its labour market reform agenda provide that necessary focus to strengthen the Australian economy. As I said at the outset, we will not oppose this legislation. But I move the following amendment to the second reading motion:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
`whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House notes that the administration of the legislation by the Government has been less than satisfactory in that:

(1) the management of public debt by the Government has seen a rise in the public debt interest component of the Commonwealth Budget to such an extent that it is now larger than expenditure on education and is equivalent to that spent on defence; and

(2) Government policies in the past saw a swallowing up of Australia's domestic savings by the public sector and caused Australia as a nation to borrow more from overseas, resulting in net foreign debt quadrupling over the term of this Government to $89 billion.'

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —That is incorrect-absolutely incorrect.

TALK.START.PARA: —When members of this House debate aspects of the intelligence and security services of Australia, I am always reminded of the observation of Mr Justice Hope:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia needs a good system of intelligence and security services. This need has become more apparent now than perhaps it was in the past . . . Australia cannot hope to know everything that is going on in every part of the world. But we can try to keep informed about what people are doing and planning in areas of special significance to us. That requires us to be more discerning in choosing subjects for intelligence collection and assessment.

If Australia is to have a good system of intelligence and security services of the highest professional standards, then the services must attract and retain people of first-rate quality and dedication. In return, Australia's intelligence and security services must be able to offer potential employees not only competitive but excellent employment packages that will include generous salaries and conditions of service.

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the employment provisions of the Australian Security Intelligence Organization Act. Outmoded references to the Public Service Board and the Secretary to the Attorney-General's Department are removed by this Bill. Although the amendments themselves are of a routine housekeeping nature, nevertheless they are necessary and urgent.

Since the abolition of the office of Chairman of the Public Service Board, the terms and conditions of employment of Australian Security Intelligence Organisation (ASIO) staff cannot be varied. As a consequence, national wage case increases that have been awarded to all workers cannot be passed on to Australian Security Intelligence Organisation staff. Section 8a of the Australian Security Intelligence Organization Act 1979 already enables the Minister to give guidelines to the Director-General of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation to be observed by the Director-General in the performance of the Organisation of its powers and functions.

The amendment contained in clause 4 of this Bill will extend to provisions of section 8a to enable the Minister to give guidelines in accordance with the section to the Director-General in the exercise of his powers of determining salaries and terms and conditions of employment of staff under sections 85 and 86 of the principal Act. Indeed all guidelines under section 8a of the principal Act are required to be tabled in each House of Parliament within 15 sitting days after they are given, except where to do so would be contrary to the public interest by reason of prejudice to security, defence, international affairs or the privacy of individuals.

Clause 6 of this Bill amends section 86 of the principal Act by omitting, inter alia, references to the Secretary to the Attorney-General's Department. The reason for this amendment is that the provision is now outdated. This reference to the Secretary to the Attorney-General's Department goes back to the 1956 Australian Security Intelligence Organization Act when it referred to the Solicitor-General who was, at that time, also Secretary to the Attorney-General's Department. Clearly, it is no longer appropriate for the Secretary to determine pay and conditions of employment of staff of another Commonwealth agency. Clause 8 of this Bill repeals sections 34 and 35 introduced to the principal Act in 1986. This is necessary as a consequence of the abolition of the Public Service Board.

The other unproclaimed sections-33, 36 and 37-relate to a change in the employment relationship of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation staff with the Dir- ector-General. Under the Act as it presently stands staff have a contract with the Director-General. The basis of their employment is therefore contractual. The amendments made in sections 33, 36 and 37 of the 1986 Amendment Act have the effect of changing this employment basis to a statutory one. Consideration is being given to whether a move away now from contractual based employment is in the best interest of ASIO. If the Government concludes that it is preferable for the employment base to remain contractual then Parliament will be asked to repeal sections 33, 36 and 37.

The administrative reforms contained in this Bill will serve well the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation. However, the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation has never faced greater challenges than it does today. Over recent years, the work of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation has undergone a considerable change in emphasis. Originally the organisation was founded to counter espionage attempted by foreign powers. It became popularly associated with the gathering of intelligence on possible sources of internal subversion, particularly after its first success in securing the defection of Petrov. More recently, the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation has placed considerable emphasis on the countering of attempted extensions of international terrorism to Australia. At present, the weight of ASIO's duties would appear to require a return to a greater emphasis on its traditional counter-espionage activities, prompted by the increasing sophistication of defence related technology to which Australia now has access.

Since the Second World War, Australia has been included in the dissemination of intelligence from the Western alliance. It is generally assumed that this exchange takes place under formal agreements, but it has been the policy of successive governments to neither confirm nor deny the existence of any such arrangements-the last occasion being by Senator Gareth Evans on 30 May 1985. Nevertheless, it is known that much information both of a tactical and a technological nature is exchanged-for instance, United States of America (USA) photo-satellite reconnaissance pictures of Soviet deployments at Cam Ranh Bay in Vietnam. Nor is this exchange one way; recently disclosed details of the Petrov affair have indicated that Petrov's information was significant in undermining the then active Soviet intelligence network in North America. Furthermore, joint defence operations in Australia have produced defence and security information shared by Australia and the cooperating nation. The first of these was the British nuclear tests, followed by the joint project at Woomera. Today, this activity is represented by joint Australian and US facilities particularly the Joint Defence Space Research Facility at Pine Gap.

Throughout the same period Australia has been developing an independent intelligence-gathering capability. Although the Australian Secret Intelligence Service provides a conventional means of gathering information on the region, it is sometimes said the most effective information has been produced by the Defence Signals Directorate. This is especially the case after two successive reviews of the nation's security agencies by Mr Justice Hope. In his General Report of the Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies published December 1984, Justice Hope said that:
In 1974 Defence Signals Directorate was impressive by any Australian standards and is impressive now . . . I have no doubt that this will continue to be the position.
Defence Service Directorate's activities have expanded since 1974, and its skills and technology have thus far substantially kept up with this expansion.

Since the report of the last Hope Commission, the Hawke Government has taken steps to ensure that the Defence Signals Directorate continues to expand its technological expertise. In the 1987 Defence White Paper it was announced that:

The Government plans to enhance our independent intelligence capabilities by establishing a large satellite communications station in Western Australia. This will contribute to Australia's security in our area of strategic interest. The station will be totally Australian owned and will be manned and operated by the Defence Signals Directorate.

There are two important aspects of this activity which link directly to the developing role of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation. The first is that the basis of Australia's military security and its capacity to become more self-reliant in its own defence lies in effective intelligence. The 1987 Defence White Paper also said:

A high level of strategic intelligence is fundamental. This allows us to review developments in the defence capabilities and political positions of other countries and to monitor them for changes that could affect us directly . . .

By continuing to develop our own capabilities and by supporting existing arrangements for intelligence sharing with allied countries, the Government will ensure that our needs for strategic intelligence of high quality will continue to be met.

As the extent and importance of this intelligence increases, so does the risk that foreign governments will attempt to gain access to it. Not only does such information have a value in its own right, but knowledge of the nature of such intelligence could well be used to support `disinformation' campaigns to complicate its assessment.

Secondly, as the intelligence networks of major powers are organised on a global scale, it must be assumed that access to US and North Atlantic Treaty Organisation (NATO) information will be sought wherever it is available and, due to our alliance connections, Australia is one such place. The nation's access to this international intelligence has been guaranteed by ASIO's ability to maintain an effective counter-intelligence operation. As Australia's independent intelligence gathering grows in strength and quality, the same precautions will apply with, however, the important development that increasingly the nation's security depends on the ability to maintain the flow of intelligence.

It is fundamentally important that the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation has a strong capability in countering industrial espionage. The Hawke Government has placed controls on the export and re-export to certain countries of technology which could be used for military purposes, ranging from computers to metals and synthetic rubber. This action was taken in mid-1987 when the Hawke Government decided to adhere formally to the guidelines established by the Paris-based Coordinating Committee on Multilateral Export Controls (COCOM) restricting the flow of commercial-military technology to certain countries. COCOM comprises all North Atlantic Treaty Organisation countries, except Iceland and Japan. Countries excluded under the COCOM agreement are Afghanistan, Mongolia, Albania, North Korea, Bulgaria, Poland, China, Romania, Czechoslovakia, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, the German Democratic Republic, Vietnam and Hungary.

Australia has a reputation as a reliable recipient of sensitive Western technology and high technology exports are increasing rapidly. Australia is therefore obliged to cooperate with its Western allies in restricting the flow of hard-won high technology that might assist the military capability of countries excluded under the COCOM agreement. It is essential that Australia's high reputation is maintained so that local companies and the Australian Defence Force are not disadvantaged and continue to enjoy ready access to advanced Western technology.

It is not the first arrangement made by the Australian government covering the exchange of high technology information. Since 1964 Australia has been a party to the America, Britain, Canada, Australia (ABCA) agreements. These agreements are aimed primarily at the cooperation, collaboration and interoperability of the armies of the US, the United Kingdom, Australia and Canada and involve the constant exchange of technological data. Although the security of this information has primarily been the responsibility of the Army and, of course, the Department of Defence, the capacity of Australia's internal counter-espionage agencies to prevent the development of any sophisticated attempt to breach such security has been critically important in the confidence of the parties in the exchange of information.

This confidence is exemplified in the fact that Australia is one of the few countries outside NATO and Japan which has full access to all US military systems offered for sale-for example, Pave Tack, now fitted to Royal Australian Air Force F111s, is operated only by the United States Air Force and the Royal Australian Air Force. The military effectiveness of the Australian Defence Force depends heavily on the ability to maintain a technological advantage over likely regional competitors. Security of access to the latest NATO standard technology must be guaranteed.

The effectiveness of ASIO in preventing illicit gathering of details of such technology is essential in maintaining the confidence of allies that they can safely sell such equipment to Australia. However, Australia's membership of COCOM is important for the development of Australia's high technology industries since the export of sensitive technology is prohibited to countries that are not members of COCOM. Another advantage of Australia's membership of COCOM is that Australian companies are able to incorporate advanced components into equipment of their own development and manufacture which may then have export potential in addition to the domestic market. The threat to the integrity of important military technology arises not only from the activities of certain nations but also from attempts by private individuals and corporations who steal and sell such technology. Honourable members will recall the treachery of certain employees of the Japanese corporation Toshiba which has since resulted in the Soviet Union acquiring new low-noise propulsion systems for many Soviet submarines.

The implementation of the provisions in this Bill will strengthen the capability of ASIO to protect the integrity of high technology acquired under the agreements to which I have referred. This Bill is designed to allow meaningful improvement in the salary and conditions of service of employees of ASIO. The Hawke Government values the important work being done by ASIO. It has always had the support of this Government and it will continue to have our full support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bill before the House, the Australian Security Intelligence Organization Amendment Bill, improves substantially the salaries, terms and conditions of Australian Security Intelligence Organisation (ASIO) staff. For that reason, the Bill enjoys the wholehearted support of the Opposition. I am particularly pleased by the fact that under the Bill the Director-General of ASIO will be able to take into account public sector policy on pay and conditions, as well as recognising the special circumstances associated with employment by ASIO.

SPEECH.PARA: Who could deny that special circumstances exist for all employees of ASIO? It is almost trite to say that ASIO officers deserve good conditions of work. They have a very demanding job, often with long hours and sometimes unrewarding work. I think most honourable members would agree with me when I say that special characteristics are needed to act as an ASIO officer-characteristics such as thoroughness, patience and an unusual degree of dedication to the service. Above all, there is a requirement for ASIO staff to have a commitment to their country-a commitment to Australia.

For that reason a number of us in the Opposition had many concerns with the shift of ASIO from its Melbourne headquarters to Canberra in late 1986. Indeed, we are advised at page 7 of the 1986-87 ASIO report to Parliament that `230 officers were compulsorily retired by the Director-General'. That report tells us that on 12 March 1986 the Director-General wrote to all the officers stationed at headquarters advising them that from 30 November 1986 they would have to shift to Canberra so as to perform their duties. At the same time, given the Government's insistence that the shift take place rapidly, officers were told that they had until 30 June in the same year to indicate whether they were prepared to transfer.

Is it any wonder that at a press conference on 28 September 1988 the incoming Director-General of ASIO, Mr John Moten, revealed that some 70 per cent of ASIO staff had left as a result of the shift from Melbourne to Canberra. The new Director-General was candid, in keeping I would think with the new image of ASIO, when he said that the move `was almost devastating'. For that reason it is terribly important that the Government address the most fundamental conditions of employment for ASIO officers. Failure to provide the necessary remuneration and incentives for ASIO officers will further weaken what is already a very weak base. The truth is that ASIO is largely staffed with inexperienced officers. However keen and dedicated they are, nonetheless they have to make up for the loss of senior and experienced staff as a result of the shift.

I agree with the new Director-General, Mr Moten, when he says that in the long run the shift to Canberra will be of benefit to ASIO. He believes that it will allow ASIO far better to obtain links and cooperate with the various intelligence agencies throughout the Western world or, more specifically, the Western alliance. Nonetheless, the Government must understand that, as a priority, ASIO staff should be properly treated so as to overcome-again to use the new Director-General's wording-this `devastating' staff loss.

On the Government's past record there is a presumption that it is less than sympathetic to all of ASIO's needs and, sadly, objectives. I do not believe that the Australian Labor Party (ALP) has ever taken ASIO seriously. It has always maintained that ASIO was engaged in activities which undermine the ALP. Conspiracy theories have always abounded at ALP conferences. Look at the way that so many members of the ALP embraced Peter Wright when he fought the battle against the tyranny of the British Government, represented by Sir Robert Armstrong, the Secretary of Cabinet, when that Government sought injunctions to prevent the publication of Mr Wright's Spycatcher book. They thought he was a hero. It was a good chance to attack the Poms anyway. It was also a chance to reveal the conspiracy by MI5 to topple the socialist British Prime Minister, Harold Wilson. For the first time their very worst fears were brought to light by Peter Wright, the supposedly highly placed MI5 agent who specified in his book that a conspiracy existed embracing a large number of MI5 officers.

In recent days Peter Wright has recanted. In a British interview he was asked just how many MI5 officers were involved in this conspiracy to topple the democratically elected socialist Prime Minister. He replied that not everybody in MI5 was involved in this conspiracy. He was then asked exactly how many were involved in the conspiracy. His reply was along the lines `basically myself'.

To the ALP, MI5 was supposed to be the prototype of security intelligence organisations, that is, that such organisations are always the instruments of service for the conservative side of politics. I do not doubt for a moment that the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), a good and honourable man, would have a very serious commitment to ASIO, to the effectiveness of its operations against domestic terrorist violence as well as counter-intelligence. Nonetheless, a presumption exists that the ALP is hostile to ASIO as it is to other security organisations.

Let me give an example of that. I will not go too far far back in history. One cannot forget the Murphy raid on ASIO headquarters in Melbourne in 1973. According to a number of commentators and observers in the intelligence community, that was the beginning of the end of ASIO. I certainly would not go that far, but the truth is that ASIO has never quite recovered from that. Let me move on lest anyone should think that I was delving into ancient history. The Combe-Ivanov affair saw the Government run away from ASIO at 100 miles an hour. There will always be a sensitive morale problem within the ASIO under an ALP government.

The latest example of the Government's neglect of ASIO, even the downgrading of its importance, was when the Government ignored ASIO's advice that a Soviet official be expelled for espionage activities prior to the visit of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to the Soviet Union in the middle of this year. I understand that the Prime Minister would have had a difficult decision to make. He was about to embark on a tour of the Soviet Union under the banner of glasnost. It was a tour during which the Soviet Union laid out the red carpet, made the Prime Minister feel very important, and gave him a very rare chance to play a role on the world stage. So there was the attraction, the lure, which proved irresistible, of self-aggrandisement by the Prime Minister.

That had to be weighed up against the implications for our relationship with the security organisations of our Western alliance partners. In my view, the Government should not have rejected the advice from ASIO, particularly when, in its annual report to the Parliament, ASIO informs us that some 50 foreign intelligence operatives are at work in this country. I would think that most, if not all, are attached in a diplomatic capacity to one or other of the foreign missions.

ASIO does not recommend the expulsion of an official of another country very lightly. It is prepared to identify and maintain surveillance on a surprisingly large number of intelligence operatives. That is the considered judgment of ASIO, and I am certainly not going to second-guess it, but it highlights the fact that, if ASIO wanted a Soviet official expelled, knowing that it was more or less on the eve of the Prime Minister's visit to the Soviet Union, there must have been good reasons for it. The Government either supports ASIO or it does not.

One of the events in the last couple of years that has concerned me greatly and has significantly contributed to a weakening in the public's eyes of the effectiveness of ASIO has been a decision by the Security Appeals Tribunal. You would know, Mr Deputy Speaker, that that Tribunal was established under the ASIO Act to handle appeals from ASIO security classifications of public servants. A judgment handed down held that past membership of the Communist Party, in itself, was not sufficient ground for ASIO to disqualify somebody from security clearance. Surprisingly, it has even been suggested by people close to ASIO who should know better that even present membership of the Communist Party is not sufficient disbarment from access to security documents during the course of employment. I reject that notion and quite frankly I do not agree with the decision of the Security Appeals Tribunal.

I do not intend to engage in an exercise of examination of the workings of communist organisations in this country, but I will say that on this occasion the Government is delving into the realms of the ridiculous if it does not believe that somebody with at least recent membership of the Communist Party, not to mention present membership of the Communist Party, poses a security threat. If such a person does not, then who does? Why bother having a security classification scheme? All ASIO can do is ask somebody whether he or she has ever been a member of the Communist Party. If the interviewee replies, `Yes, I have' presumably ASIO then asks, `Do you still adhere to the beliefs of the Communist Party?' If the reply is yes, ASIO then asks, `Would you ever use physical violence to achieve the objectives of the manifesto of the Communist Party?' If the interviewee replies no, the next question in this line of thought, I would imagine, would be, `Would you ever deliver documents of a security nature available to you to other members of the Communist Party?', to which the answer obviously would be no. In that case, ASIO cannot go beyond that. The burden of proof of security reliability in a case like this must surely rest with the public servant. Apart from using a truth drug or torture-heaven forbid-how does ASIO ever know the true intentions of a person other than by his or her track record? What predisposition do such people have, and who can belong to the Communist Party and be a true democrat?

There are other problems for ASIO which I hope the Attorney-General will address in summing up and on which I hope the Government will take action. For the life of me, I still cannot accept the need for or the role of the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security. This is also a brainchild of this ALP Government. To what extent does the Government want ASIO to be accountable? In the first instance, it is accountable to the Attorney-General and, through him, to the Cabinet and in turn to the Parliament. It is accountable to the Australian Audit Office and to the Joint Parliamentary Committee on ASIO, of which I am a member. We have to draw the line somewhere. Just what does the Inspector-General do? What we do know is that expenditure for the Inspector-General's office for the year ending 30 June 1988 was almost $265,000. What did we get for that? We got a glossy cardboard cover with three pages inside it which told us practically nothing. He told us in that minuscule report that there were 13 complaints against ASIO during the year-eight from the public, four from within the organisation. He found that three of these were beyond his jurisdiction and he dismissed all the other complaints except one which is still being considered. I would have no problems with the role of the Inspector-General under those circumstances but for the fact that it is so hopelessly expensive. Mind you, some sections were deleted after the Department of Defence expressed concern that he was making public some highly sensitive material on the Defence Signals Directorate. Even so, I think it would still be a very short report.

The Inspector-General does not stop there, because he makes a complaint that the law has frustrated his inquiries in that he does not believe that he can properly counsel dissatisfied ASIO staff because under the Act employees are prohibited from divulging work-related information to him-and so they should be. So why do we have this supposed ASIO watchdog? Why do we spend so much money? I do not think that we need an Inspector-General whilst under our Westminster system the Attorney-General must front up to the Parliament, nor do I think that this Inspector-General, by nature of the law and the need for secrecy, can perform any sort of serviceable role.

Do we trust ASIO under the present accountability requirements or do we not? I have sought to bring together a number of threads and call upon the Attorney-General to assure us of the Government's deep and abiding commitment to ASIO, because when these threads are drawn together and examined collectively the presumption that has existed for decades that the ALP is hostile to ASIO is reinforced, if anything. We know that ASIO is an integral part of the security of this country. Whatever happens between the superpowers, whatever the easing of tensions in the relationship between the Soviet Union and the United States and western Europe and eastern Europe, the fact is that we must remain vigilant. After all, there have been serious allegations, seemingly authoritative, that the second ranking official in the Soviet Embassy is considered to be a KGB spy. Mr Valery Zemskov has been referred to by an international publication as a senior member of the KGB. Mr Zemskov, a very urbane, witty and influential diplomat, dismissed these allegations in typically impressive style when he said:
. . . I have to disappoint you . . . I am a career diplomat. I spend all my time in the foreign service. I'm quite satisfied and happy with my job . . .

He went on to say that he found it very flattering to be in the limelight. The Attorney-General really needs to support ASIO. This legislation will do so to some extent. The Government must address morale problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank all honourable members for their contributions. The honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown) quite effectively dealt with the relevant parts of the Australian Security Intelligence Organization Amendment Bill and supported them. SPEECH.PARA: I thank the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) for his contribution. He gave a very learned expose of what the task of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation (ASIO) has been and is, and its enormous number of difficulties. We are all deeply indebted to ASIO for its work. It is an essential part of our democratic structure. I have the highest regard for all of its officers. The former Director-General did a marvellous job in arranging what one might call the removal of ASIO from Melbourne to Canberra. That was not an easy task but it was done with the greatest of skill and integrity. ASIO has been fully occupied, basically, with dealing with counter-terrorist activities, which in many ways have concerned people in Australia.

I want to go quickly through some of the remarks made by the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran). The honourable member for Gippsland is a colourful speaker, but he really does not do himself justice when at times he creates the impression that there have been some problems with ASIO-for example, that it was obliged to move from Melbourne. TALK.START.PARA: —I was simply making the point that there is an inherent problem.

—The honourable member was very critical of the move. He would have known that an earlier Government spent a lot of money, millions of dollars, constructing a building in Canberra. He would have known that that was a recommendation of the Hope Royal Commission, but he never adverted to that. I have to remind him of that. He then said that the move may have affected morale and staff. Look at what is said in a report of what Mr Wrigley, the former Director-General, has said about that. Mr Wrigley said that a number of claims that the Government had allowed ASIO to lose valuable staff were incorrect. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: ASIO staff numbers are slightly higher than when I came in mid-1985.
In fact, they were at full strength, at a level of about 738 staff. He went on to say:

Because only about half of ASIO's total staff worked in headquarters, the 70 per cent loss there represented only a 32 per cent loss overall. Most of those lost were clerical rather than intelligence people.

Naturally what we would call supplementary staff would not have seen their way clear to move from Melbourne; they would have found alternative positions. So ASIO is very strong and morale is very good. It will get even better now that we can fix terms and conditions more speedily. It does not do the debate any good to suggest that there is something wrong with ASIO. As I say, it is a first-class organisation.

I make no comment on the Security Appeals Tribunal other than to say that of course there will always be argument as to what a judicial tribunal might say. The judge on the Security Appeals Tribunal was appointed by the Fraser Government. Setting up a tribunal and making appointments had nothing to do with us; they already existed. I pass no other comment; nor am I able to.

The position of Inspector-General is again a recommendation from Mr Justice Hope, made on the basis that there should be some opportunity for people who feel that ASIO is not carrying out its charter to have their complaint independently investigated. I am delighted to know that the reports are so thin and contain so little information. That proves that ASIO has not got much to answer for. There are always plenty of people who will complain. The fact is that the honourable member just wanted to use up a bit of time, but he could have done that by praising ASIO and realising that the issues we are discussing are no cause to be so derogatory of the system. I make the point that, in a bipartisan attitude, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) is privy to all information-the lot. That was not mentioned. These are the problems we have.

Suggesting that there is something wrong with ASIO is a waste of time. It is a first-class organisation of extreme value. If I might say so with some sense of humility, it has not in any way deteriorated under my administration, and I give it my fullest support. We have a new Director-General who will do a first-class job. Morale is very high. Individuals may at times feel that they have a grievance, but such matters do not come to me; they are dealt with within the Department itself.

I do not know why I need to talk about Spycatcher or Peter Wright. Again, that matter has gone to the judicial tribunals of Australia. I have some interest in those tribunals, and they are amongst the best in the world. If people fail in the witness box, if they fail under cross-examination, we should not blame the judge; we should blame the people who gave the evidence. That is the problem. It is not much good suggesting that because someone comes to Australia his evidence cannot be tested. In fact, if someone comes to Australia and does well in the witness box. he should do well elsewhere in the world.
I thank honourable members for their contributions. The legislation will be a great asset to ASIO, and I thank all honourable members for their support of this splendid organisation.
