When we were finishing our talk a lot of people got their copies of that policy and covered them with sand in the creek bed. They left some corners of the papers sticking out. They were buried behind Mr Howard when he was talking on Sunday. People told me they could still see the corners sticking out. Mr Howard walked over some of them while he was there.
Anangu did this because they did not like the policy. They were sorry about it. They want it to go away. It is a bad policy.

In my speech I talked as Chairman for Anangu Pitjantjatjara. I said what our people wanted me to say. Did Mr Howard and Mr Tambling expect me to ignore their new policy, their new plans for us if they become government?
I am blind so I cannot use notes when I make a speech. I sometimes get a friend to help me, to remind me what I want to say next by reading what I have prepared. It is my speech, not my friend's.
Mr Howard and Mr Tambling say white people put ideas in our heads. That is not true. Our heads are not empty.
When Mr Howard came to Ernabella, he had many advisers with him. None of them were Aboriginal. I will say no more about that.
We want to work with Mr Howard, with his party and the National Party. We are not happy about everything the Labor Party does.
We will not be treated like children. Do not use us for your political fights. We speak for ourselves.

Those people have condemned outright the policy of the Opposition with regard to Aboriginal affairs. I will state what that policy is aimed at. First and foremost, it is the intention to undermine the confidence of the white Australian community in the ability of Aboriginal people to manage their own affairs. Once that is achieved Opposition members will have won the battle to white-ant the proposal to establish the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. That is what their campaign is all about. If, along the way, people's characters are assassinated, people's reputations smeared and their civil liberties thrown to the wind, it does not matter to the Opposition. It can hide safely behind parliamentary privilege.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Halverson Mr R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tomorrow the citizens of the United States of America will vote to elect a new President. Therefore, it seems an appropriate time to examine the record of the man who will soon be vacating the White House. It will be some years down the track before Ronald Reagan's many outstanding initiatives during his eight years as President of the United States are properly analysed, and the significance of many of his achievements fully recognised.

SPEECH.PARA: Like many before him-and probably many who will follow-history will no doubt judge him far more kindly than some of his contemporaries whose opinions are clouded or influenced by factors such as political preferences and ideological differences. One thing, however, is beyond question: Ronald Reagan has succeeded in renewing the faith and restoring the pride and confidence of Americans-in themselves; in their great country; and in all that America stands for and being an American represents. He has elevated the sagging morale of a nation that had begun to question where it was at, and where it was going. And he did it so successfully that he won, and retained, office with two landslide victories. He has also shown that age is not-as it should not be-a major factor or deterrent in determining one's ability to participate in the public and/or political arena.

Perhaps one of the most contentious areas of President Reagan's administration was his policies on world peace. The reasons behind his advocacy of the concept of peace through security-reductions in offensive weapons in conjunction with defensive strategies and initiatives-were summed up by his 1980 presidential campaign statement:
Of the four wars in my lifetime, none came about because the United States was too strong.

The inability to defend oneself never has been, is not, and is never likely to be, the best or most effective way of guaranteeing or maintaining world peace. Reagan's peace initiatives have been based on the realistic and accurate premise that, `nations do not distrust each other because they are armed. They are armed because they distrust each other'. His approach to world peace issues and his policies of non-proliferation, deterrence and diplomacy recognise and reflect this fact. An editorial in the Australian Financial Review of 16 May this year, entitled `The Strange Record of Ronald Reagan', opened with the statement:
It is easy to bag President Ronald Reagan, and by now it is a sport which almost the entire world delights in following.

But instead of succumbing to the temptation to jump on the `let's have a go at Reagan' band wagon, the author of this editorial presents a rather refreshing evaluation of the Reagan years and, I believe, a very accurate analysis of Reagan's leadership style and achievements. Again I quote from this editorial:

It is also by now a plain historic fact that this rather unusual form of world leadership has not led to any disasters-indeed, that over the years it has compared more than well in terms of results with many US presidencies.

. . . He has led the United States, and therefore most of the non-communist world, . . . in a style which has been totally his own. The principal thing that can be said about this is that it is a triumph of democracy. In whatever way it may be viewed, the Reagan era has in no way been a disaster.

. . . On balance, Mr Reagan emerges as the kind of amazing politician who may actually have been the right man in the right place at the right time. Whether the same thing will be said about his successor is something the whole world will be waiting to find out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Townsville Grammar School celebrated its centenary this year. It was on 16 April 1888 that Townsville Grammar School opened its doors and admitted 23 boys as students. There are grammar schools in other States, in England, and no doubt in other countries, but the grammar schools of Queensland are unique. They were set up in terms of the Grammar Schools Act passed by the Queensland Parliament in 1860. The Queensland Government sought by this method to bring the benefits of secondary education to the youth of Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: Boys and girls grammar schools were established in Ipswich, Brisbane and Rockhampton and boys grammar schools in Toowoomba, Maryborough and finally, on 16 April 1888, in Townsville. Management of each grammar school is vested in seven honorary trustees, four of whom are Government nominees, and three subscriber representatives. The current trustees are the Chairman, Mr Frank Dixon Sim-to whom I am indebted for the preparation of this speech-Jim Thompson, Professor Ted Scott, Errol Wenck, Mrs Marcia Bird, Ross Marsh and Arthur Bloxham.

The first headmaster appointed was Mr C. H. Hodges. However, he did not arrive until the commencement of 1889 and in the interim the school was under the control of Mr E. F. Upward, who had conducted a private school in Walker Street, Townsville which he had called St John's High School and the building `Edgecombe'. Mr Hodges stayed at the school until the end of 1900. I mention two important events during his headmastership. Firstly, during the second term of 1893, Miss Mary Foley was enrolled as a student. Her father, the member of parliament for the district, could see nothing in the Act which precluded him from enrolling his daughter and, as a consequence, Townsville Grammar School became the first coeducational grammar school in Queensland and indeed the first coeducational secondary school on the mainland of Australia. Miss Letitia Crowder was enrolled at the beginning of third school term of 1893. Both Mary Foley and Letitia Crowder passed Sydney Senior Examination in 1896 and subsequently joined the Education Department.

Mr F. T. Millar was the Headmaster of the school from 1901 to 1904. During his term, the school suffered one of its greatest catastrophes. On 9 March 1903 Cyclone Leonta almost destroyed the main building of the school. The school opened in 1905 with a new Headmaster, Mr P. F. Rowland. He was to lead the school with great distinction until the end of 1938. Mr Rowland was a dynamic personality revered by generations of students. He was known and respected throughout the north not only for his leadership in the field of education but for his `Essays in Brief' published weekly in the Townsville Daily Bulletin. His tenure encompassed the First World War, and the names of the 150 old boys and masters who fought in that conflict, including 21 who gave their lives, are recorded on the honour board in the vestibule of the present administration building.

Mr T. B. Whight took over the headmastership at the commencement of the 1939 school year. Amongst his assistant masters who also started then was Mr M. W. Blank, who was to assume the headmastership in 1948.

With the entry of Japan into the war on 7 December 1941, and subsequently with the fall of Singapore, Townsville was brought directly into the front line of potential conflict. Schools were closed, many families left for supposedly safer areas in the south, and the Royal Australian Air Force took over this school. Mr Whight, in the 1946 school magazine, had this to say:
The attack on Pearl Harbour prevented the realisation of our great expectations. Enrolments were immediately cancelled by telegram and telephone and local enquiries ceased.
These years were indeed difficult ones for Mr Whight; it was not surprising that he decided to relinquish his headmastership and return to Sydney at the end of 1946.

Mr A. C. Logan was Headmaster from the commencement of the 1947 school year. In 1948 Mr M. W. Blank assumed the headmastership. Mr Blank brought great vigour and determination to the task of rejuvenating the school. Numbers increased. Nineteen fifty-five saw the building of the then science building. The new dining room, kitchen, the senior dormitory-schoolroom building and the memorial swimming pool were added during his tenure. The Headmaster, Mr Blank, had indeed rescued the school and accomplished much.

Mr L. S. Daniels was appointed Headmaster from the commencement of 1966. By then the concept of government aid to independent schools was firmly accepted and the Schools Grants Commission established. The present Headmaster, Mr Alan Morwood, took over the headmastership at the commencement of the 1976 school year.

Townsville Grammar School now has approximately 600 students, both boys and girls, day students and boarders. My children, Eamon, Amelia and Joseph, attend Townsville Grammar School, which is one of the finest schools in Australia. The people of north Queensland congratulate Townsville Grammar School on its centenary, its distinction and its provision of education to the people of north Queensland.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to draw the attention of the House to a very serious problem occurring in my electorate of Gippsland at this very moment. It is the threatened withdrawal of private hospital benefits for aged patients in two bush nursing hospitals, Heyfield and Mirboo North. It is causing a great deal of stress to aged people, their families and the communities in which they live. Madam Speaker, this is an issue that you would be well aware of, but other honourable members of the House may not because the bush nursing hospital system is unique to Victoria. It is a system that has been strangled by Medicare slowly but surely since its introduction five years ago. We are now at the last chapter of a very sorry saga.

SPEECH.PARA: The situation is that there are a number of patients at the Mirboo North Bush Nursing Hospital and lesser number at the Heyfield Bush Nursing Hospital who may well have their benefits withdrawn by the Hospital Benefits Association Ltd and the Australian Natives Association. Given that the percentage of people who now insure with private health funds is down to an astonishing 51 per cent from a high of 85 per cent prior to the introduction of Medicare, the private health funds simply cannot afford to pick up the tab for the small number of patients in bush nursing hospitals who are there for other than medical reasons.

The blame cannot be laid at the feet of the private health funds, as the Federal Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) seeks to do. The truth is that the responsibility for the situation we have now reached which is causing so much fear and uncertainty for these aged people and their families lies with the Government. In the first instance the Government should make adequate arrangements for the supply of nursing home beds so that these people are not in hospitals. They are in acute bed hospitals and the private health funds are paying out some $35,000 a year for each of these patients to remain in that care. Of course, the economics are such that, when this is added to all of the other deadly blows to the private health funds inflicted by Medicare, the funds simply cannot afford this any longer. There is nowhere for these people to go. There are no nursing home beds available in Gippsland; nor would I think there is a spare bed anywhere in Victoria.

Look at what the Hawke Government has done to the health funds. It has reduced its contribution to the hospital benefits reinsurance trust funds from $100m in 1982 to $1m in 1988-89. It has abolished the Commonwealth bed day subsidy to private hospitals. It has increased the benefits funds have to pay for psychiatric and rehabilitation patients. The Government has presented the funds from accumulating special reserves to cover long term patients. It has forced the funds to pay for prosthetic implants previously provided by the state. All of these moves, plus others, have reduced the capacity of the health funds to meet the costs of hospital patients who by rights should be in nursing homes. That is the place for them-not in acute beds. There is a great deal of anxiety throughout a number of small communities in Gippsland directly affected by the Government's latest measure in this area. The Federal Minister described the health funds as callous and their behaviour as unacceptable. In point of fact, those words apply to the Minister's policies, which have forced the funds and their contributors into an impossible position.

I call on the Government to take account of these aged patients at the Mirboo North and Heyfield bush nursing hospitals and in other places throughout Victoria. Approximately 145 patients are in these small country and bush nursing hospitals. Only one-Pyramid Hill-has been advised by the health funds that its long term patient refunds will be withdrawn. But Mirboo North and Heyfield are at very serious-indeed critical-risk. I call on the Government to take care of these aged people and to accept its proper responsibility by providing a sufficient number of nursing home beds.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent Mr L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make some comments on the latest attempts by the Australian Medical Association (AMA) to increase doctors' incomes. Let me say at the start that I have the greatest respect for general practitioners. However, my respect does not extend to the AMA. Usually when workers ask for a $5 or $10 increase in pay there is a large outcry from the Opposition. It is some time now since the AMA announced its proposals for increased doctors' pay, yet honourable members opposite have been strangely silent. I have been patiently waiting for them to condemn the AMA, but in vain. So I thought I would take up the issue for them.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is willing to accept changes to the charging system, but only if it results in improved services and only if it does not lead to an increase in the cost of health both to individuals and to the community. Under the new AMA proposed fee structure, patients would be charged according to the content of the service provided rather than according to the time spent providing the service, which is how the system presently operates.

The fee structure proposed by the AMA will in no way improve the standard of care given to patients. The AMA proposal is only a cynical attempt to increase doctors' incomes at the expense of consumers and taxpayers. The current average yearly earnings of general practitioners are very high compared with average weekly incomes. Doctors have received a 5.4 per cent rise in schedule fees which was introduced on 1 August this year. Since the election of our Government, the standard general practitioner consultation fee has increased by between 40 and 60 per cent. This compares more than favourably with increases in the consumer price index. Doctors have done very well for themselves, given the general level of restraint that has been shown by the general community.

If these proposals are implemented, this massive pay rise will be met directly by patients, most of whom do not earn the same high salaries as their doctors and have not received a 40 to 60 per cent pay rise in the last five years. Yet, despite this, the AMA has proposed a new fee structure which will raise the average yearly incomes of doctors to $156,000-a 30 per cent increase over the current level.

Patients will have to pay in one of two ways. Firstly, the cost of a visit to a general practitioner will increase dramatically. Under the present system a standard consultation at a surgery during business hours costs $18.60, which means that the patient has to pay $2.75 after the Medicare rebate. Under the AMA's proposals, this will increase to $21.50, meaning that $5.65 will have to be paid by the patient. Secondly, if the Government increased the Medicare rebate to cover the increased charges, the taxpayer would be hit by nearly $680m. This would mean increased taxes.

The current schedule fee the Government recommends to doctors is a charge that the Government considers to be fair and reasonable for a particular item. This recommended fee covers practice costs and provides a reasonable income for the doctor. The Government has no powers to enforce such fees and doctors are free to charge what they wish. The only power that patients have over doctors' charges is to shop around. Before they go to the doctor, people should ring up and inquire whether the doctor is charging under the new AMA proposed scheme. If he or she is, the patient should go elsewhere. In my electorate I have had my Hotham prices watch group carry out a survey of general practitioners to discover how many have adopted the new pricing scheme. Of 21 respondents to this survey, only three general practitioners-or 15 per cent-have adopted the new scheme. I am glad to say that the AMA does not have the support of the vast majority of general practitioners in this latest endeavour of private enterprise to stick its snout in the public trough.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I would like to say something about the presidential election in the United States, which is taking place at this very moment. It is my strongly held view that it would be in the best interests of the people of Australia, as well as in the best interests of the people of the United States, if George Bush were to be successful in that election. I am sure that honourable members on the other side of the House would agree with me that what we, as Australians-as supporters of the Western alliance-need, and what is best for the people of the United States, is to have in the White House somebody who has experience. The experience of George Bush as the American Ambassador to the United Nations, as the American Ambassador to China, and as the United States Vice-President for eight years, far exceeds the experience that Governor Dukakis has had. His experience is confined almost solely to the boundaries of the State of Massachusetts.

SPEECH.PARA: It is also extremely important for the Western alliance, including Australia, that the United States continue with its foreign policy of peace through strength. It is the Bush administration which would continue the policy of peace through strength-not offering to give up every weapons system the United States has before negotiations with the Soviet Union begin. I have noticed with great concern that Governor Dukakis has offered to give up weapons systems such as the MX missile, Midgetman and even the strategic defence initiative system before beginning negotiations with the Soviet Union.

I submit that that does not make much sense. George Bush would certainly not do that. He would certainly continue to negotiate with the Soviet Union from a position of strength. That policy has been an overwhelming success during the period of the Reagan Administration. It has forced the Soviet Union to the negotiating table on international matters, particularly intermediate-range nuclear force weapons. It has forced the Soviet Union to the negotiating table over Afghanistan and to withdraw from Afghanistan. It has forced it to wind back its involvement in Africa. It is forcing the Soviet Union to reduce its involvement in Central America.

It is very important that the United States maintain a policy of economic growth. Again, that is what George Bush is committed to doing-not increasing taxes, which is a policy so familiar to Australians. We have seen it from our own Treasurer (Mr Keating) and Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). That is the policy in the United States of Governor Dukakis. George Bush has said that there will be no tax increases, that the Budget deficit will be wound back through a freeze on spending and that economic growth will generate additional revenue. But there will be no increase in taxes. So, there will be no stifling of economic growth in the United States. If economic growth in the United States is stifled, then it is a sure thing that a country such as Australia, already struggling with a balance of payments crisis and declining living standards, will suffer all the more.

The final point I make relates to international trade. George Bush has continually supported the cause of lower protection and a freer international trading regime. Whilst we in Australia have reservations about some of the things the Republican Administration has done in the area of international trade, it is important for this country that protectionism, as advocated by Governor Dukakis, be cast aside and we have a freer international trading regime. If the Americans vote for Governor Dukakis, it will be a step into the wilderness, into the unknown. If George Bush wins, there will be certainty and security.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 24 May 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the Australian Inventory of Chemical Substances.
(2) When were companies and organisations first asked to nominate chemical substances for inclusion in the inventory.

(3) Are agricultural chemicals, food additives and human and veterinary drugs included in the inventory; if not (a) what is the basis for their exclusion, (b) who made the decision to exclude them and (c) when was this decision made.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian Inventory of Chemical Substances will list industrial chemical substances manufactured in or imported into Australia for commercial purposes.

The Inventory will be an integral part of the Government's proposed national scheme for notification and assessment of industrial chemicals. The Government recently agreed to drafting of legislation to implement the proposed chemicals scheme. The scheme will represent an important advance in protecting people and the environment from the hazards of chemicals.

Under the provisions of the proposed chemicals scheme, the Inventory will serve as the means of distinguishing existing chemicals, which will be selectively notified and assessed, from new chemicals which will be subject automatically to notification and assessment.

(2) The Inventory is being compiled in phases so as to minimise the overall effort required by industry and by the Government. It will be based upon nominations submitted by manufacturers and importers of chemical substances.
The first nominations to the Inventory were made in 1984 and involved selected major chemical manufacturers and importers. From this process a core Inventory was published later that year.
In 1986, all chemical manufacturers and importers were asked to nominate substances. This input provides the basis for a draft Inventory to be issued in September 1988.

Because of the longer than planned time taken to finalise the details of the chemicals notification scheme, it was decided, after a review in 1986-87 by interested Ministers, to extend the eligibility period for chemicals to be included in the Inventory. This will mean that chemicals manufactured in or imported into Australia for commercial purposes between 1 January 1977 and 30 June 1988 may be nominated.

To accommodate this amended provision a third (final) phase of nominations will take place between September and December 1988. The completed Inventory will be published in the latter part of 1988-89.

(3) The chemical constituents of agricultural chemicals, food additives and human and veterinary drugs were eligible for nomination to the Inventory in the first (1984) and second (1986) nomination phases.

The Ministerial Committee which reviewed aspects of the chemicals scheme decided that the constituents of these chemical products should be excluded from its scope. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has since introduced into the Parliament the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Bill 1988 to establish a statutory national clearance system for agricultural chemicals and veterinary drugs to further promote national uniformity in the assessment and control of them.

The chemical constituents of agricultural chemicals and the other chemical products mentioned need not be nominated in the final phase of nominations to the Inventory. Those nominations provided previously will remain as part of the Inventory.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 26 May 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a call by the British National Radiological Protection Board (NRPB) for reductions in the permitted dose of radiation received by workers and the general public as a result of the latest analysis of the Hiroshima and Nagasaki bomb survivor studies which doubles the fatal cancer risk from radiation exposure.
(2) Has the Government undertaken its own analysis of those studies; if so, which Department is undertaking the analysis and what are the results.
(3) If the Government is not analysing those studies, why not.

(4) Was the information regarding the Hiroshima and Nagasaki studies and the position of the NRPB considered during the revision of the Code of Practice on Radiation Protection in the Mining and Milling of Radioactive Ores (1980); if so, why are the annual dose limits for designated employees and the general public set at 50 millisieverts (mSv) and 1 mSv, respectively.
(5) Does the Minister plan to further revise those limits to those proposed by the NRPB to 15 mSv and 0.5 mSv, respectively; if not, why not.
(6) If the limits are to be revised, when is this expected to take place.

(7) Is the Minister able to say why the International Commission on Radiological Protection (ICRP) has decided to take no immediate action to reduce the internationally accepted limits despite a statement issued in September 1987 by the ICRP agreeing with the analysis of the Hiroshima and Nagasaki bomb survivor studies.
(8) What steps is the ICRP taking to investigate reducing the internationally accepted limits.
(9) Are there dangers posed to workers in the nuclear industry and the general public by the IRCP's delay in recommending reductions to those limits.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable member's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories is aware of the recent interim guidance of the UK National Radiological Protection Board (NRPB) regarding radiation exposure of workers and the public. The NRPB guidance was that the average dose for radiation workers should not exceed 15 mSv per year, although the limit should remain at 50 mSv per year.

(2) The National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) is the Commonwealth body in Australia which formulates and makes recommendations on radiation protection standards. These recommendations are then incorporated by State and Territory health authorities in their radiation control legislation. Advice to the NHMRC is prepared by its Radiation Health Committee (RHC) as relevant information becomes available.

The Director of the Australian Radiation Laboratory of the Department of Community Services and Health is Chairman of the RHC and is also the Australian representative on the United Nations Scientific Committee on the Effects of Atomic Radiation (UNSCEAR).

The Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories is responsible for oversighting the formulation of Nuclear Codes of Practice under the Environment Protection (Nuclear Codes) Act. A Commonwealth/State Consultative Committee draws on expertise available from Commonwealth agencies, the States and the Northern Territory. Advice is also sought from industry and the union movement as appropriate and successive Ministers have sought public comment in the development of codes of practice.

(3) At present, the UNSCEAR and the Committee on the Biological Effects of Ionizing Radiation (BEIR) are reviewing all the data available from the Japanese studies, as well as from other studies undertaken in the past. Until these reviews are complete, it would seem to be premature for the Radiation Health Committee to offer advice to the NHMRC.

(4) The text of the Code of Practice on Radiation Protection in the Mining and Milling of Radioactive Ores (1987) was finalised during 1987, and took account of the most up-to-date information available from the ICRP. The ICRP, in its Como Statement (September 1987), drew attention to the possibility that the present risk factors may be low. The Como Statement did not warrant suspension of arrangements to promulgate the new Code.

(5) Neither the NRPB, nor the International Commission on Radiological Protection (ICRP), have changed the annual dose limits for workers and the public from 50 mSv and 1 mSv respectively. The NRPB has issued interim guidance only, which recommends that, for the most highly exposed groups of workers, it would be prudent to adopt a time-averaged effective dose equivalent of 15 mSv per year. The NRPB recognizes that it may take a few years to achieve this objective for some groups of workers, but this would be equivalent to only a few additional years of occupational exposure. For members of the public, the recommendation is that the annual dose limit from effluent discharges from a single nuclear site should not exceed 0.5 mSv per year. It is understood that the authorities in the UK have not yet taken up these recommendations.

The Radiation Protection (Mining and Milling) Code 1987 adopts limits currently recommended by the ICRP and NHMRC. It also adopts their recommendation requiring that doses be As Low As Reasonably Achievable, economic and social factors being taken into account (the ALARA Principle). The implementation of this principle has resulted, over the years, in doses received by radiation workers being very much lower than the annual limit.

(6) The limits specified in the Radiation Protection (Mining and Milling) Code may be reconsidered following changes, if any, recommended by the NHMRC's RHC. I am advised that any proposed changes would be based principally on ICRP recommendations.

(7) In its Como Statement the ICRP refers to the fact that the risk factors currently in use appear to be low, as a consequence of the recent studies on Japanese survivors. However the results of these studies are, as yet, far from conclusive and a more detailed study needs to be undertaken.

(8) The ICRP is undertaking a review of its present radiation protection recommendations but before finalizing risk factors and proceeding the new dose limits, it is awaiting the outcome of the UNSCEAR and BEIR review of all available information. It expects to complete its revised recommendations by 1990.

(9) As the ALARA principle has been used for many years, the doses received by most radiation workers are very much lower than the present annual limit. Very few workers would receive doses which exceed an annual value of 15 mSv. Nevertheless, the RHC is preparing a statement for general dissemination to draw attention to the possibly different risk factors and the need to introduce further precautions to reduce doses wherever possible.
